title: Do Memory Palaces Work? The Mind-Blowing Science of Learning at Scale
description:
Do Memory Palaces Really Work?

Yes, and the science backing the memory boosts this ancient technique provides will blow your mind.

Also known as the method of loci, Memory Palaces were used by ancient scholars and are still used by world memory champions and contemporary learners.

Even Sherlock Holmes used the "Mind Palace" technique in some of the most famous stories ever written and brought to the screen.

But does this ancient memory techniques actually work, or is it just another brain-training myth?

In this video, I'm taking you deep into the science of memory to see what multiple researchers have discovered about mnemonic techniques and whether they truly help with memory improvement, retention, and recall.

title: I tested subliminals for "super memory and intelligence" so you don't have to
description:
Do subliminals work?

I risked 14 days of my life and the health of my ears to find out.

Why?

Although I'm not personally chasing the promise of memory subliminals for a sharper mind, many people do hold out hope that these kinds of recordings will help them.

Spoiler:

Subliminals for better memory and pretty much everything else are a scam.

In this video, I share my own experiments and research to expose a brain training fraud that left me with nothing but the exact results I was expecting.

And the scam I uncovered?

Shocking.

That statement isn‚Äôt hype. It‚Äôs my raw, unfiltered reaction.

That's why were debunking memory subliminals once and for all in this video.

title: Mastering Long Form Content in a Short Attention Span World
description:
Are you sick of losing out thanks to a short attention span?

You start a long video you need to watch... only to find yourself mindlessly scrolling shorts 10 minutes later?

If so, you're not alone.

Some experts claim that the average attention span dropped to just 47 seconds.

This is a tragedy because the most valuable content often comes in longer formats.

Here's the very good news:

I've discovered a powerful combination of two ancient memory techniques and modern solutions that will transform how you learn from long-form content.

Imagine being able to watch hour-long videos and actually remember the key insights days, weeks, or even months later.

How valuable would that be for you?

In this video, I'll show you how to combine a special, revolutionary note-taking system used by some of history's greatest thinkers, with the Memory Palace technique.

Together, these methods will help you not just watch long-form content and read long and challenging books, but truly absorb and retain what you learn.

Whether you're a student, professional, or lifelong learner, this unique approach will change how you consume online content forever. Let's dive in and unlock your mind's full potential.

title: The Weird Reason We Sometimes Mix-Up Words (And How To Fix Your Memory Slips)
description:
üß† Ever wondered why your brain occasionally throws a linguistic curveball, swapping names or mixing up words?

You're about to find out because today I'm unraveling the fascinating cognitive science behind those awkward verbal mistakes that happen to everyone... no matter how good you might be at language processing normally.

It's all inspired by a slip of my own where I said "Roger Gilmore" instead of "David Gilmore."

What seems like a mistake actually reveals incredible insights into how our brains process language, memory, and communication.

Key Insights in This Video:

1, The real reason behind unexpected name mix-ups.

2. Why frequent speakers are MORE likely to experience verbal slips.

3. Why pros use teleprompters to aid their careers as professional communicators.

4. How memory actually works (spoiler: it's not what you think!).

5. The neuroscience behind verbal mistakes, especially in situations where presentation skills face heavy cognitive load.

6. Why these memory retrieval slip-ups are a sign of cognitive complexity, not failure.

7. Presentation strategies that leverage your brain's natural processing with tips guided by memory science and my communication research as someone with an MA in Media Studies.

8. How memory retrieval actually works in real-time communication and why verbal slip-ups are not always an indicator of brain performance or cognitive function.

üö® NEXT VIDEO ALERT:
  
In my next groundbreaking analysis, I'm exposing the MAJOR problems with photographic memory that nobody talks about. üì∏üß† 

You won't believe the scientific truth behind this supposed "superpower"!

title: Is 'Getting Better At Anything' Too Good to Be True? Scott Young Responds
description:
Is it really possible to get better at anything?

In this video, I sit down with Scott Young, author of "Ultralearning" and his new book "Get Better At Anything," to discuss and sometimes challenge this bold claim.

Scott and I dive deep into accelerated learning techniques, rapid skill acquisition, and the realms of how educational claims and pedagogical ideas get scientifically tested.

Scott shares his insights on memory hacks, deliberate practice, and cognitive flexibility. We discuss the power of spaced repetition, the meaning of better and the controversial notion of copying others in order to learn.

Whether you're a lifelong learner, productivity enthusiast, or simply curious about unlocking your full potential, this conversation will give you practical tools to supercharge your learning journey.

üîî Subscribe now and hit the notification bell to stay updated on more interviews with learning experts and thought leaders!

üëÄ Want an idea for what to watch next?

Don't miss my fascinating chat with Luke Ranieri on language acquisition and the power of immersion learning. We explore mnemonic techniques, the input hypothesis, and various aspects of how to learn foreign languages. It's the perfect companion to this episode with Scott Young!

title: Will Military Pilot & Language Expert Luke Ranieri Successfully Memorize The Iliad... by Singing?
description:
Luke Ranieri is the man behind the incredible YouTube channels Polymathy and Scorpiomartianus.

On top of being a pilot and teaching people ancient languages, he's also currently memorizing the first 100 lines of the Iliad.

That's why I just knew I had to talk to him and dive into how he's approaching this task.

He's already set the stage by producing the excellent Iliad 100 where you can hear him singing the lines and get them for yourself with instructions on his approach.

We discuss dealing with ancient languages at large in this interview, along with unfolding the art of memory at large, with a special focus on the Memory Palace technique for verbatim.

Here are Luke's main channels:

https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCLbiwlm3poGNh5XSVlXBkGA

https://www.youtube.com/@ScorpioMartianus

Thanks as always for checking these videos out and your interesting comments!

For another deep dive into memory techniques for verbatim projects, check out this discussion with Ashley Strand, who memorized the Book of Mark next:

title: How I Got A+ Grades in University And How You Can Too!
description:
If you're struggling to get top grades in university and want real, no-nonsense study tips that will transform your GPA, this tutorial is for you.

I faced many obstacles in university, some of them self-imposed. Avoiding the problems I created for myself will be of huge benefit for you.

By the same token, I did a lot of things right (obviously, since I got so many A grades and even A plusses). Some of what you're about to learn is never discussed and teachers/professors do not want you to know about some of these strategies.

How do I know? Because I used to be a professor myself.

Either way, tune in as I reveal the exact steps I took to achieve A+ grades throughout my university career, including in grad school. Given that I later become a professor who graded students, I think you'll especially appreciate my perspective.

You'll discover some of my best:

* Time management tips for balancing your study, work and personal life

* Effective ways to show up even when you don't feel motivated

* How to make sure you always have the best possible places for optimizing your study habits

Follow-up with my deep dive tutorial into how to use The Memory Palace technique for studying:

https://youtu.be/c4J5ZUzCxZY

title: The Memory Palace Technique For Studying
description:
The Memory Palace technique for studying breaks down to having 5 core mnemonic strategies working together.

In this detailed tutorial, I'll share the five Memory Palace systems that I used for studying at York University and the European Graduate School. I still use this technique to this day in a modified version I also share with you for more casual remembering.

So if you want to master the Memory Palace technique for studying specifically, you're going to love this detailed tutorial.

title: Using Mnemonics in Everyday Life: The Ultimate Guide
description:
People often asking me about using mnemonics in everyday life.

There are many ways you can use memory techniques on the go.

All you need is to have your main five mnemonic systems set up.

Unfortunately, no one can develop these learning tools for you. But they're easy to understand and get into use. Most people can master basic mnemonics in a weekend or less.

Then, the intermediate techniques like the Memory Palace are easy to master in a week or so after that. It really just comes down to your vision and desire.

That's why in this deep dive study of how to get mnemonics into use in your everyday life, I'll also help you demolish all of the key objections people face when it comes to setting up their systems and using them consistently.

Ready for another MMM "masterclass" on the fundamentals that make your memory great?

Let's do this thing!

title: How Did Actor Ashley Strand Memorize OVER 10,000 Words & Deliver Them Live On Stage In Record Time?
description:
When Ashley Strand told me about his live performances of The Book of Mark, I knew I had to interview him.

In this wide-ranging discussion, we talk about the "real work" that goes into memorizing a verbatim text of over 10,000 words.

Whether it's Shakespeare or scripture, I can tell that Ashley really knows his stuff. And as a huge fan of live theatre, I wanted to spread the word about his performances.

Plus, I've memorized texts totalling over 2000 words in Sanskrit. So I think you'll appreciate some of the granular details we get into based on our shared experiences.

We discuss, for example, the importance of textual analysis as an aid to memory.

Then there are some fantastic strategies related to the Memory Palace technique that will help pull you through some of the stickier elements that arise when memorizing verbatim.

The way Ashley combines the method of loci with textual analysis is super-fascinating.

To learn more about Ashely Strand and book tickets to see him perform The Book of Mark live, visit his site:

https://www.kingjameslive.org/

Thanks as always for your interest and support and talk soon!

title: Visual Memory Techniques: Two MUST HAVE Hacks To Memorize Quickly & Effectively
description:
Visual memory techniques involve an ironic twist...

One that many people who teach the art of memory fail to teach you.

Never fear. Dr. Metivier is here.

Learn these two hacks and you will instantly get more out of the visual memory techniques you use.

The first hack is something I've been using for years to learn faster and remember more. Sadly, a lot of people are missing out on it due to the tools used in contemporary culture.

The second hack is counterintuitive.

title: Would Socrates have RISKED his memory just to fiddle around with ChatGPT?
description:
It's fairly well-known that Socrates worried writing would destroy human memory.

Clearly, he was wrong.

Yet...

There are reasons to take his warning very seriously. We just need to look at it from a different angle.

As I discussed in last week's video about Giordano Bruno's memory techniques, after all, mnemonics have been a kind of artificial intelligence all along.

title: Giordano Bruno's "Artificial Intelligence" & The Ultimate Truth About How To Remember Everything
description:
Some people say that Giordano Bruno thought you could know, understand, remember and direct all knowledge in this world.

Literally all of it!

Well... I interpret the great memory master rather differently. In this video, I discuss the "artificial intelligence" of the Memory Wheel Technique when used in combination with the Memory Palace.

When your definition of "everything" is correct and accords with the true information of information, perhaps you've got a shot.

But it's not necessary. There are better options and I explain the most important mnemonic encoding tool I've found in his books.

Learn to use it well and your practice with memory techniques will explode.

Want to know more about Giordano Bruno and his interesting approach to mnemonics?

Check out The Chaos Memory Palace of Giordano Bruno next:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NcM3VBdlIvc

title: 5 Personal Mantras That INSTANTLY Create Inner Harmony (And Are Easy To Remember)
description:
I've been using personal mantras for a long time.

But good ones can be hard to find.

And some are long and complex and require elaborate memory techniques like the Memory Palace to remember.

I know because I've memorized a ton of them!

That's all fine and dandy. And I highly recommend it.

But sometimes you just want personal mantras that are easy to remember within seconds. And settle your mind just as quickly every time you need them.

Give these 5 mantras a try and let me know which ones you like best for yourself.

title: From Life Crushing Anxiety To PERFECT Calm: USA Memory Champ John Graham's BEST Stress-Busting Tips
description:
John Graham has mastered his memory AND his emotions.

That includes the ability to banish stress and anxiety on demand.

There's so much suffering out there, and that's why I'm grateful John has opened up about his devastating experiences with fear, inner distress and other issues that make it hard to live the good life.

description:
A lot of people ask me for memory improvement book recommendations.

I've definitely got them.

The problem is...

There are even better books out there that will improve your memory.

Sometimes they are called "spiritual" books or meditation books...

When in reality, they are books that will improve your memory...

title: How Do You Know What's WORTH Memorizing? Real Life Sherlock Holmes Ben Cardall Explains
description:
Ben Cardall, the real life Sherlock Holmes is back...

This time to answer tougher questions about the weaknesses of deduction and induction based on the varying qualities of information.

In other words, you might like to think of yourself as having the critical thinking skills of a Sherlock Holmes... but there's more to it than just observation. You must also be able to weigh, evaluate and remember.

If you can't do that, it can be really difficult to figure out what's worth memorizing when using the Memory Palace technique.

As a professional detective combined with years of experience in performance, Ben is a fantastic student of human nature, behavior, psychology. Because he uses memory techniques himself, his insights are golden.

Not just for figuring out what to memorize, but for thinking about other topics too. Along these lines, I couldn't resist questioning Ben on my favorite pet topics.

I'm taking about free will, how he approaches the Memory Palace technique and finding out what's coming in the new version of his epic guide, The Monographs.

Find Ben Cardall on YouTube here:

https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC4-_FoMtz95usjzrwQjydPA

title: Why You ABSOLUTELY MUST Learn The Masterful Memory Techniques of Robert Fludd
description:
Robert Fludd is one of the greatest masters of mnemonics in history.

His understanding of how and why we need to use Memory Palaces based on real locations is superior.

He explains number systems like no one else, providing incredible details on how to use number pegs. He even reveals an early version of what we now call the Major System.

Robert Fludd recently received the royal treatment from Lewis Mason books in an English-Latin translation called Mnemonic Methods that I highly recommend.

More than recommend it, we're taking a deep dive into the most masterful aspects of Fludd's incredible training.

And we'll look at some aspects to avoid as well.

Thanks as always for your hitting that thumbs up, leaving your comments and sharing these tutorials around!

title: This is practice
description:
What do you practice?

And how?

So much hinges on how consistently we show up.

And what we work on when we're there.

Not to mention our mental attitude and constitution.

In this video, I share some ideas that I hope will help you keep showing up.

I also show one of my favorite practices for near-daily mental stimulation. It's powerful on its own, but is especially useful because it is embedded in other activities I practice to boost my memory and my cognitive faculties overall.

As Confucius said, "poor, yet delighting in the way. Rich, yet a student of ritual."

title: How Writing Protects Your Mind and Builds Memory with Essay Founder Julian Peterson
description:
Julian Peterson has created Essay.app to help people think more deeply about their ideas.

That way, they're worth structuring in the best possible order before you write a word.

It's an especially interesting time to be working on software for writing too, so I was heartened when I heard Julian defend the value of "doing it yourself" in the age of AI.

On that note, I'm writing this video description myself even though I could get a bot to do it for me.

Why is it so important?

For one thing, writing provides incredible working memory exercise ‚Äì mental stimulation I'd be missing if anyone else ‚Äì or any thing ‚Äì were to do it for me.

And as Julian and I discuss, the act of writing frequently structures your mind in a way that leads to a better life further on down the line.

Find out more about Julian Peterson and Essay.app here:

https://essay.app/home/

https://www.instagram.com/julianpeterson1/

https://twitter.com/julianpeterson1

title: St  Augustine On Memory: Insights You Can Use To Improve Your Practice
description:
St. Augustine was a memory master I've been asked about often.

People want to know if there's anything practical they can use from his philosophy of memory, specifically when it comes to the Memory Palace technique and mnemonics.

Yes, but the real value here is about the organization and categorization of knowledge in your pursuit of self-awareness.

When you understand how he described memory and the ultimate mnemonic device God himself used to remember information, you'll have something far better than practical information.

You'll have food for thought that feeds you forever.

title: How to Remember Trivia & Random Facts
description:
There are two ways that we can think about trivia:

Learning how to remember trivia for winning games and competitions.

Or just being able to absorb incoming facts, no matter how trivial they may seem.

title: Memory Alchemy & A "Magnetic" Tarot Reading With Brad Kelly, Author of House of Sleep
description:
When I heard about the memory themes in Brad Kelly's House of Sleep...

I just knew I had to read it!

Good thing I did too. It's not only a great story, but is a literary meditation on the nature of memory.

There are multiple levels of memory exploration too, including themes of grief, medical shamanism and the ultimate redemption through enlightenment.

Brad Kelly is also an expert tarot reader, so he got out the cards and gave the Magnetic Memory Method itself a reading!

Enjoy this episode and be sure to check out Brad's podcast Art of Darkness for more interesting discussions of highly memorable literature:

https://www.youtube.com/@artofdarkpod

title: The terrible irony of Nietzsche's most memorable line
description:
One of Nietzsche's most powerful quotes is butchered beyond belief.

Yet, there's probably a memory-science reason behind why the incorrect version is so "sticky" in so many minds.

In this video, we analyze "Whatever whatever doesn't kill you only makes you stronger."

You'll see the full quote in context and learn more about what Nietzsche likely really meant.

And if my hypothesis is correct about what makes the incorrect version of this quote so memorable, you'll be able to avoid inadvertently spreading wrong ideas around.

title: Understand This About Mental Imagery & SUPERCHARGE Your Memory Forever
description:
Mental imagery is one of the most misunderstood aspects of using memory techniques.

You don't have to be creative.

You don't have to be visual.

You don't even have to be unique or original.

You just need to understand what mental imagery is really all about so you can finally make progress when using mnemonics, tactics like the method of loci and the Memory Palace technique.

Watch this video and soon you'll be enjoying much longer lasting mental associations that make it easier and more fun to remember anything you need to retain.

title: Beyond Mnemonics: Exploring the Road to Enlightenment With 3x USA Memory Champ John Graham
description:
Of course it's fun to use mnemonics.

They can help you learn languages, pass exams and become a better professional.

But one thing I love most about 3x USA Memory Champ John Graham is that he goes beyond the obvious applications of memory techniques.

And in this episode of the Magnetic Memory Method Podcast, John and I discuss how memory training could possible help you enjoy experiences of enlightenment.

Actually, that might not be the best possible word for what we're talking about. 

But that's part of the problem. Language can be the portal to finding our higher selves. Or it can be the barrier.

Dive in, enjoy and we look forward to hearing from you in the comments!

title: Why Critical Thinking Is Important For Leading A MUCH Better Life
description:
You want to know why critical thinking is important?

So many people never tell you the full story. 

That's why in this video we're taking about critical thinking for better decision making.

There are key principles and easy-to-remember acronyms you can carry with you everywhere.

Make better decisions, escape problems in advance and keep your memory free from unnecessary clutter.

That way you'll be free to learn more at a greater clip than ever before.

title: Is The Zettelkasten Method Really The Best Personal Knowledge Management System?
description:
When it comes to Personal Knowledge Management systems, I've been using the Zettelkasten Method since 2000.

It sounds completely bonkers.

But it works, and there are good scientific principles that underly its incredible effectiveness.

I prefer to use the Zettelkasten system in combination with Memory Palaces for best results.

It enables fast and effective spaced repetition. Speaking of which, you might want to watch my training on that topic next:

title: The Art of Memory: Is It Really The 5-Star Memory Improvement Book Some People Claim?
description:
The Art of Memory is one of the most successful memory improvement books.

But is it any good? 

Is it even really a memory improvement books at all?

Above all, did Frances Yates use mnemonics herself?

We're taking a deep dive into one of the most popular books on memory of all time.

For someone who wrote books that I wish were more popular, including a deed-dive tutorial, check out this study of Hugh of St. Victor next:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Nv3WSP1f4y0

0:17: üìö Intro to the 'The Art of Memory' by Francis A. Yates, who never tried the memory techniques she wrote about.
2:43: ü§î Questions about being a writer contributing to good memory.
4:45: üìö Various mnemonic strategies and their connection to Giordano Bruno's cosmological ideas, with some disagreement regarding whether Bruno was a Hermeticist.
7:02: üìö The Art of Memory is a valuable resource for learning about the history of memory techniques, but may not be the best for improving memory skills.
9:50: üí° The art of memory is a craft, science, and martial art of the mind that involves critical thinking and using memory to make better decisions and solve problems quickly.

title: Prospective Memory: How to Remember the Future Using a SIMPLE Memory Palace
description:
Defining prospective memory is not as easy as it looks.

But once you've mastered it, you can literally remember the future.

I'm talking about future events like appointments and tasks. This type of memory is also hugely important for habit formation.

You'll learn a simple Memory Palace tactic for remembering things you need to do as we explore this fantastic form of memory.

Basically, developing your prospective memory comes down to rewiring your brain, and there's more on that in this deep dive into neuroplasticity:

https://youtu.be/VRMHV9ao7wM

Thanks as always and talk soon!

title: The Memory Wheel of Ramon Llull For Generating POWERFUL Mnemonics & PROFOUND Critical Thinking
description:
Ramon Llull is legendary for many things, but in our world of mnemonic strategies, he's especially well-known for his memory wheel strategy.

This unique memory technique has influenced many philosophers, mathematicians and memory masters, including the legendary Giordano Bruno.

Is it still worth exploring today? Yes, I believe so.

There are 4 key ways to use Memory Wheels. In this video, we'll cover them all, taking our New Art of Memory Series to yet another level.

title: The Memory Palace for Language Learning
description:
Tired of forgetting new vocabulary and struggling with grammar rules while immersing yourself in a new language?

Join me on a journey into mnemonics for language learning as we explore the extraordinary world of the Memory Palace technique, a game-changing memory strategy that will revolutionize your language acquisition!

In this video, I'll guide you through the step-by-step process of creating your own MEmory Palace properly.

Sometimes called a Mind Palace, this special mnemonic device is where familiar locations transform language learning into an unforgettable adventure. Learn how to associate language items with specific locations, turning them into visual cues that stick in your memory like never before.

And I'm not just talking about individual words. I'm talking about entire phrases too.

We'll also delve into a treasure trove of other effective language learning strategies: reading, writing, speaking, and listening all synergize with the Memory Palace technique, amplifying your language fluency.

When you immerse yourself in engaging texts, create meaningful connections through writing exercises, practice speaking with confidence, and sharpen your listening skills to unlock a whole new level of comprehension, the adventure gets better and better.

If you'd like more, don't miss out on the opportunity to supercharge your language skills with my upcoming Language of Memory Live Cohort.

title: From Cardiac Arrest to Fearless Bible Memory Before the Congregation
description:
Have you ever wanted to memorize Psalms from the Bible?

If so, delve into the extraordinary story and memory tips gifted to us today by Matt Barclay. I mean, get this:

Matt experienced traumatic memory issues following a cardiac arrest. Miraculously, using the Magnetic Memory Method, he recited almost an entire Psalm from memory.

In public. Without breaking a sweat.

Matt's experience is a true testament to the power of resilience, memory techniques, faith and using the Memory Palace to accomplish big goals.

Especially inspiring is how Matt rose up from the cognitive challenges created by a cardiac arrest to become a fearless master of Bible memory. 

In this heartfelt conversation and strategic analysis of how he approaches memorizing scripture, Matt shares his profound insights, guiding us through the intricate process of harnessing the mind's potential to recall and recite scripture with unwavering confidence.

Prepare to be moved and inspired by Matt's incredible journey, one that exemplifies the unyielding human spirit and the triumph of action over adversity. 

Don't forget to click that subscribe button and stay tuned for more uplifting stories and remarkable individuals like Matt Barclay.

title: The Moon Memory Palace Technique of Alexander Dicsone
description:
The New Art of Memory would not be complete without covering the Moon Memory Palace Technique, developed by the ingenious Alexander Dicsone. 

Alexander Dicsone was a renowned memory expert and scholar during the Renaissance. He devoted himself to writing two books about memory techniques. These are gathered in English translation with the original Latin in The Hermetic Art of Memory.

As Discone covers the standard mnemonic strategies, he also unraveled many of the mysteries of human consciousness. His groundbreaking technique involves using the Mansions of the Moon as a kind of Memory Palace.

In doing this, Discone was inspired by the method of loci, but also aspects of astrology.

Dicsone was also a student of Giordano Bruno, the brilliant philosopher, astronomer and master of memory. Many of Bruno's innovative ideas laid the foundation for the Moon Memory Palace Technique, influencing Dicsone's work and propelling it to new heights.

In this video, I'll guide you through the step-by-step process of creating your own Moon Memory Palace. 

Even better, I'll show you ways to maximize the space on the moon and even use "infinite" moons. Together, we'll explore the lunar corridors, each room and "mansion" serving as a repository for your precious memories.

But the journey doesn't stop there! I'll also share valuable insights on optimizing your Moon Memory Palace, enabling you to unlock the full potential of your mind. With practice, you'll find yourself effortlessly memorizing facts, speeches, languages, and so much more.

Join our community of memory enthusiasts today by clicking that subscribe button and thanks as always for your interest and support.

title: Harry Lorayne, The Zero Memory Palace Mystery & Why His Memory Improvement Books Inspired The World
description:
Harry Lorayne was one of the greatest memory experts of all time.

And thanks to his many books, videos and all who remember his great teaching of the art of memory, he influence will live on.

Author of the great, How to Develop a Super Power Memory, Lorayne was also a talented magician, speaker and promoter of another skill:

Card magic.

Memory and sleight-of-hand go together because mnemonics are sleight of mind in many ways.

Lorayne's ability to do both remains inspiring, on top of his many other talents.

I hope you enjoy this profile of the legendary Harry Lorayne, and thank you as always of your support and interest in this channel.

title: The Imaginary Memory Palace Method of Hugh of St. Victor | Training Drills & "Noah's Ark" Case Study
description:
How would you like to use a Memory Palace over and over again?

One that has dozens of stations in it? If not hundreds?

Hugh of St. Victor created Memory Palace training exercises that might help you create them.

Even better:

He made a Memory Palace based on Noah's Ark that he used to teach his students the art of memory.

In this detailed case study, I take you into the teaching of Hugh of St. Victor.

Drawing upon his Mystic Ark lectures, the Didascalicon and commentaries by Conrad Rudolph, Ivan Illich and Mary Carruthers, you're in for a real treat.

Thanks so much for your support of this channel and special thanks to Ronald Johnson of The Craft of Memory Podcast for suggesting In the Vineyard of the Text. Check out his show here:

https://open.spotify.com/show/65w2UEh24E3uHFFJCNvU4D?si=t0vcSPiKSJanqBv5bgYtpQ&nd=1

title: Aristotle's Nuclear Alphabet & Bi-Directional Memory Palace Mastery | Ancient Memory Techniques
description:
Aristotle's De Memoria is one of the most powerful memory improvement books you'll ever read.

Also called by the title, On Memory and Recollection, Aristotle includes a passage about using alphabetical mnemonics.

However, as clear as I feel this memory training passage is, it has also confused many scholars.

I believe we can solve this confusion by relating the Memory Palace technique to music.

I also believe anyone can learn to use any Memory Palace bi-directionally and I give you some mnemonic examples of how this will work.

Thanks as always for supporting this channel and I look forward to your thoughts on this approach to mnemonics.

--- Further Resources ---

The Art of Memory: Frances Yates, Giordano Bruno And The Mnemonic Tradition

title: Focus First/Memory Second For Business and Lifestyle Success? 2x USA Memory Champ Shares His Secrets
description:
John Graham surprised me twice on the same day!

First, I found out that he'd won the USA Memory Championship... again.

I mean... who has the time?

Then he tells me that focus is so much more lucrative and useful than memory...

And to make matters even more confusing... he keeps telling people not to meditate in the morning?

Well, I really had to get to the bottom of all these things.

And so I did in this EPIC discussion of how John really succeeds.

And you'll be surprised to discover that memory improvement training doesn't even get second fiddle.

After hearing what he has to say and giving it some consideration, I think it all makes sense.

And I think it will help you incredibly too.

So dive in for an epic discussion packed with takeaways and talk soon!

Oh, and for a few more focus tips, please see:

title: Can A Person With No Sense Of Direction Stop Getting Lost? A Conversation With Christopher Kemp
description:
Ever found yourself turning down an unfamiliar street, only to struggle to retrace your steps?

Why does that happen?

How about back before GPS, when you would pull over to the side of the road and struggle with a map?

If you've experienced situations like these, there's hope.

That's because there's one author in particular who has no sense of direction to speak of. And that makes him the perfect science writer to explore what direction is and how we might optimize it.

Even better, in Dark and Magical Places, Christopher Kemp explores how the brain produces your sense of direction.

You'll also learn why some of us might struggle to keep on track or lose our way in space.

We delve into some of the common mistakes people make and get into some of the "metaphysics" behind space itself.

Whether you're a seasoned traveler or someone struggling to get around your hometown, you'll find this discussion useful.

I highly recommend reading Dark and Magical places and hope you enjoy this interview with Christopher Kemp.

For more resources, a few years back, I created this tutorial on how to memorize any address:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=i2shzBN1tNo

title: 3 Simple Hacks To Use Instead of Motivation For Memory Palace Learning & Success | #shorts
description:
In the comments on my previous video about short term vs long term memory, username Not Again wrote:

"Dear Anthony 
I started practicing for improving my memory watching your videos and other sources as well both researching and learning everything i can find on the internet. title: Short Term Vs Long Term Memory & How To Quickly Improve Both At The Same Time
description:
Short-term memory and long-term memory are two different types of memory that play different roles in how we process and remember information. 

Short-term memory is responsible for holding onto small amounts of information for a brief period of time, while long-term memory is responsible for storing larger amounts of information for longer periods of time. 

In this video, you'll discover the differences between short-term and long-term memory and give examples of how they work in our daily lives. We will also discuss some strategies for improving your memory and keeping your mind sharp.

Why should you care?

Well, there are several benefits to improving short-term memory, including:

* Increased ability to focus and concentrate on tasks, leading to better performance in school or at work.

* Improved ability to retain and recall important information, such as names, phone numbers, or instructions.

* Enhanced problem-solving skills and decision-making ability.

* Reduced forgetfulness and improved memory for daily tasks and events.

It gets even better because the benefits of improving long-term memory include:

* Improved ability to retain and recall information over the long term, such as memories from childhood or historical events.

* Enhanced ability to learn new skills and concepts, leading to better performance in school or at work.

* Increased ability to remember important details and events, such as dates, appointments, or directions.

* Reduced risk of cognitive decline and age-related memory loss.

title: Ancient Memory Techniques
description:
Ancient memory techniques are amazing, and all the more so when you include multiple locations and periods of time.

As we go through this list together, two things:

There‚Äôs no particular order of importance here. I‚Äôm just laying out all the great techniques I‚Äôm aware of from around the world and throughout time.

You‚Äôll notice some crossover between these techniques, if not repetition. That‚Äôs because all memory techniques appear to be spatial in one form or another. 

Further, as Giordano Bruno has said in many of his memory books, if anyone thinks long and hard enough about these techniques, they‚Äôll reach the same conclusions.

These techniques might seem like they belong to or originate with a particular group. Certainly, everyone should take pride in their history. 

But because there is so much crossover between these techniques, we should see the common humanity in them and not arrive at some kind of tribalism. 

--- Bookmarks ---

title: How To Use A Novel As A Memory Palace | Fictional Mind Palace Tips
description:
What if rapidly creating and using a Memory Palace was as simple as looking at books you're already reading in a different way?

It is that simple and in this video I'm taking you inside one of my most fun and treasured accelerated learning tactics.

It helps you remember the names of characters as you're reading and also quickly create entire new Memory Palace Networks over time...

Almost without having to think about it.

Here are the steps:

0:16 My first fiction-based Memory Palace
0:41 NOTR Memory Palace drawing example
1:48 A Tentative History of Story-Based Mnemonics
2:17 Are Memory Wheels Memory Palaces?
3:01 Ars Memorativa and Ars Combinatoria
3:20 Bruno teaches the Memory Palace in Opere Magiche
5:04 Robert Fludd vs. Imaginary Memory Palaces
7:16 A novel that has locations designed to become Memory Palaces
8:52 Step one with example
9:38 Step two
10:13 step three with example
12:14 Stella Fissa is the real goal
12:41 Step four
14:42 Challenge and neurogenesis
15:49 A new Memory Palace is this simple

title: The Chunking Memory Strategy Explained
description:
You‚Äôve probably heard of the chunking technique and thought it sounded pretty boring.

I mean, how is splitting large pieces of information into smaller pieces supposed to help you remember more?

Isn‚Äôt that just more work?

Your intuition is correct to ask.

Because if the chunk method is poorly executed, it not only leads to wasted time and energy.

It doesn‚Äôt provide the desired results either.

So to fix that, let‚Äôs go beyond the standard chunking definition.

And I promise that after you‚Äôre read each and every example I have to share on this page, you‚Äôll always get great results whenever you‚Äôre chunking information.

Ready?

title: Ars Notoria: Rapid Learning or Mindfulness Guide? With Dr. Justin Sledge from Esoterica
description:
The Ars Notoria was copied thousands of times, ostensibly because of its supposed ability to help the reader learn topics like geometry, astronomy, logic and math quickly.

Not just quickly.

We're talking about rapid acquisition of dense knowledge, a lot of it was not always interwoven.

To help us understand this book's relationship to memory and learning, I'm joined by Dr. Justin Sledge of Esoterica:

https://www.youtube.com/c/ESOTERICAchannel/featured

Dr. Sledge has a great video on Ars Notoria you can check out here:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vv0plm9SVIo

We also talk a bit about Enochian, as it relates somewhat to the idea of rapidly acquiring knowledge. Here's one of Dr. Sledge's treatments on the topic:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ns9zLz1x-y4

What do you think?

Could a text like this help you learn faster? Or do you suppose any benefits must have arisen from the benefits of mindfulness?

Thanks to Dr. Sledge and as ever to you for your support of the Magnetic Memory Method initiative and talk soon!

title: Mind Map Tactics: Tips & Examples For Memory, Creativity & Focus
description:
What is a mind map?

It's an incredible tool that creates better memory, creativity, focus and comprehension.

You can even use a well-formed Mind Map as a Memory Palace if you follow certain rules.

And with these mind map techniques, you'll soon find your creativity, memory and focus will soar.

Ready?

This video takes you through my best tips based on years of experience using mind mapping for different purposes.

title: How Would Sherlock Holmes Use Memory Techniques If He Were a REAL Detective?
description:

Thousands, if not millions of people first heard of the technique through him.

The question is...

Would Sherlock Holmes be able to use memory techniques successfully if he were a real detective in the 21st Century?

Watch this video to find out as I share some of my best tips for using your memory to learn and remember anything.

title: This Brain Exercise Will FRY Your Mind And Then Set It Free
description:
The ultimate brain exercise should help you experience a new state of consciousness.

In fact, it would help expose not only the nature of your thoughts.

It would help you experience the "field" of consciousness into which your thoughts appear.

And when done correctly, it will help you experience lasting mental peace and focus because you can control your thoughts on demand.

I'm talking about literally accessing a state of "no mind" whenever you want it.

title: How Much Ukrainian Can I Learn In 30 Minutes?
description:
When it comes to language learning, it's important to have goals and a driving passion.

Given recent world events and some of my personal history, I thought it would be fun and interesting to learn some Ukrainian. Indeed, a few days ago, I posted on our community tab a call to my fellow memory experts to hop on a live stream to promote world peace. I thought I would introduce the idea of learning Ukrainian together.

However, I only heard back from one of them, so when I saw that Steve Kaufman opened the Ukrainian section of Lingq for free, I took immediate action.

Booking time with a tutor is not free, but you must have exposure to native speakers in order to learn effectively.

So let me introduce you to my new Ukrainian tutor, Ekterina. Here's her YouTube channel:

https://www.youtube.com/c/LearningWithEkaterina

As a follow-up to this video, I recommend:

3 Ways to Use the Memory Palace Technique For Language Learning

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NIWifVBN3h8

Thanks as always for your support and interest in the Magnetic Memory Method.

Talk soon!

title: If Memory Techniques Are So Great Why Isn't EVERYONE Using Them? (5 POWERFUL SOLUTIONS)
description:
I've probably been asked this question about memory techniques a thousand times...

If things like the Memory Palace are so great...

Why doesn't everyone have a full A-Z Memory Palace Network?

Today's the day for a full answer to the question.

Not only that, but we're going to blow apart a variety of myths, such as those about "learning styles."

Make sure to check out this TEDx Talk for more information about that:

Learning styles & the importance of critical self-reflection | Tesia Marshik

As always, I look forward to your thoughts, and thank you for supporting the Magnetic Memory Method initiative!

Sincerely,

title: Why is philosophy important?
description:
Why is philosophy important?

And more interestingly...

Why is a philosophy of memory important?

It seems to me that it's been a good long while since anyone has gone deep into the topic, so let's start on some admittedly general terms.

The important of philosophy simply can't be undervalued, provided that you realize you're always doing it and learn how to sharpen the ways you're doing it.

Why study philosophy?

1. To live a better life

2. To analyze and assess information more intelligently.

3. Enjoyment

4. To bring order to your life

... and there are many other reasons beyond this we're discussing in today's video.

So if you're ever wondered about the purpose of philosophy, I hope you enjoy and pick up some of the books I've mentioned.

And if you need help getting into the abstract thinking philosophy entails, watch this video next:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pBYBu-Qystc

Thanks as ever for supporting this channel with your likes, shares and comments. 

Talk soon!

title: How to Apply the 80/20 Rule to Reading Faster And Remembering More
description:
When it comes to reading faster and remembering more, you might have heard about the 80/20 Rule, a.k.a. the Pareto principle.

But how exactly do you apply it to improve reading and learning skills?

Should you count the words per minute you read?

Will it damage your reading comprehension?

The answer to both questions is a resounding, "No!"

If you want to know how to read faster and retain more, you need two kinds of 80/20 analysis. 

And what I share in today's video will help your motivation as it increases your memory abilities.

Please also see this video in the context of last week's video:

Did Ancient People Really Memorize Entire Books?

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=20En1Nm8VOY

And these two:

How to Memorize a Textbook: A 10 Step Memory Palace Tutorial

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eIQRiqQFKQY

Interleaving: A Speed Reading Technique That Actually Works

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3U34nJGuFvQ

What do you think?

Does this way of looking at how you're reading books sound like it's worth a try?

title: Did Ancient People Really Memorize Entire Books?
description:
Something has puzzled me for a long time about the idea that ancient people memorized entire books.

Really?

In my own projects with using the Memory Palace technique and committing large amounts of information to memory, I know it's possible.

But there seems to me an obvious "gotcha" in the entire notion, and it turns out that some cultural anthropologists have revealed part of what that niggling doubt is all about.

Of course, I'm including some of my best tips on how to memorize verbatim information, including how to think about the process and set yourself up for success.

I'm talking about:

* Memorizing any paragraph or passage
* Memorize a speech
* Memorize a poem

For more resources related to this video, please see:

How to Memorize a Speech In One Night Using A Memory Palace

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gBvKFI7AlLE

How to Memorize Paragraphs, Sentences, and Passages Fast

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=x9aepJcY9II

Sincerely,

title: Use A Memory Journal And These 3 Mind Mapping Exercises To Boost Your Confidence
description:

A Memory Journal is one of the best ways to boost your confidence when using memory techniques.

Not only can it help with your memory planning.

It also helps you gain self confidence because you're able to benefit from three major effects discussed in today's video.

But that's not all!

The three mind mapping tactics I'm sharing are fast, easy and fun.

title: How to Organize Your Memory Palace Networks... So They're UNFORGETTABLE
description:
Have you ever worried that your Memory Palace efforts will go to waste because you can't remember...

What you remembered?

Never fear.

It's fun and easy to use the Memory Palace technique and all the more so when you use it correctly. 

As Richard Baker framed the question:

"I can use memory techniques to remember lists of information regarding different topics, to-do lists of different categories, or have more than one memory palace location that might have different sub-locations or serve a different purpose.  So I am no longer relying on passive brain processes to store this information.  But I am still relying on passive brain processes to remember what I have learned.  By indexing, I mean a way to build a reference of what you have in your memory so you won't forget that either.  If I have a useful list of concepts memorized in case I have to survive in the wilderness, but don't have some kind of index to remember that I have remembered that list in the first place, I might not remember that I have that list remembered.  Or I might have a good memory of all the stuff I stored in a given memory palace/location, but if I eventually have 20 memory palaces and forget the "entry point" to one of them, I might not be able to get back to that string of connections that leads me to remember all the stuff in that palace except by accident.

Right now I'm just trying to have a master list of lists to remind me of the things I've built, but it feels convoluted and like it will get too long soon and I was wondering if there were other approaches that were more elegant."

I think it's a great question and I hope my answer sets Richard's mind at ease AND yours. 

The fact of the matter is that the best way to get results from the Memory Palace technique is to dive in and start using them.

And I hope today's explanation helps you do that.

For more help, check out my FREE Memory Improvement Kit at:

https://www.magneticmemorymethod.com/yt

title: Remember Numbers Easily: Entire Phone Books & Anything Else | A Discussion With Tansel Ali
description:
We've been talking a lot about memorizing large volumes of information, and Tansel Ali is one of the best. 

In this discussion, you'll learn how he memorized two phone books. That's a lot of numbers!

And if you've ever wanted to know how to remember numbers easily (or anything else), you'll want to pay close attention to this episode.

Frankly, I was surprised to hear exactly how Tansel used mnemonic strategies to pull it off ‚Äì it‚Äôs a somewhat different approach than what we normally talk about. 

Tansel Ali is the author of The Yellow Elephant and How to Learn Almost Anything in 24 Hours.

Can you really learn how to remember anything in 24 hours?

title: Ron White on Achieving a Black Belt Memory, Memorizing 2300 Names & Mastering Your Mind
description:
If you want to improve your memory and concentration, you need Ron White's Black Belt Memory Course. 

I recently completed Ron White's Black Belt Memory Program myself. Check out the introduction to see what it looks like. 

Now, you might be confused. Why would someone who already knows a great deal about the techniques take another memory improvement program?

That's just the thing:

An expert knows the limits of their knowledge. They know that they don't know what they don't know. 

And to learn even more about what I don't know, I reached out to Ron and suggested this discussion. 

I learned even more than I was expecting! 

In this exclusive interview with Ron White, we go deep into the origins of this course. 

And we dig deep into the granular details of what makes memory techniques tick. We talk about:

* The Memory Palace technique (or Mind Palace, method of loci, etc)

* 00-99 PAO and the Major System

* Using these techniques to complete LARGE learning goals

* The value of old memory improvement books

* The important of active recall and review for establishing long term retention

* ... and much, much more.

Don't know Ron White of @Brainathlete?

He is a two-time Memory Champion and incredibly talented mnemonist and memory athlete. 

He's an author, speaker and charitable individual who uses his memory techniques to demonstrate their power in multiple ways.

His Afghanistan Memory Wall project is one example of just how much anyone can achieve with these techniques while bringing great meaning to the world of mnemonics. 

Learn more about it here:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FJK8BPLQFsQ 

And of course, subscribe to Ron's channel here:

https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCrn5bzpRYOKVJoRoYvn8mPQ

When arranging this interview, I promised Ron I would do everything in my power to make the discussion EPIC.

title: Why Teaching And Teachers Fail You: A Conversation With John Danaher
description:
Don't you hate it when you learn NOTHING from a course?

It's the teacher's fault right? 

Not so fast. 

It's entirely possible that even the best teacher is fighting a tradition and system that's rigged to fail. 

Not only that, but there's the question of what makes an experience "meaningful" in the first place, let alone educational.

That's my I'm glad John Danaher had some time to chat about a compelling article he wrote.

It's called:

"The Trouble with Teaching: Is Teaching a Meaningful Job?"

https://philosophicaldisquisitions.blogspot.com/2021/05/the-trouble-with-teaching-is-teaching.html

What I love about this article, and John's blog overall, is the deep analytical thinking about the topic. 

I also really like his book "Automation and Utopia," but it was this first article that got me hooked on his writing style.

It's very clean, clear and direct. Sometimes VERY direct at how it demolishes some of our ideals about things like teachers and teaching.

Sure, eschewing the romantic can be painful.

But Radical Honesty is what the MMM Initiative is all about. 

So do as I've done and follow John Twitter so you don't miss a thing he shares:

https://twitter.com/JohnDanaher

title: Aboriginal and Indigenous Memory Techniques & No More "Memory Wars" with Tyson Yunkaporta
description:
Are you curious about the memory techniques used in the ancient world? I'm talking about aboriginal memory techniques in Australia and all sorts of indigenous tools for learning and retaining information.

If so, you're in luck. In this video, I sat down with Tyson Yunkaporta, an author and educator who has shared these techniques with many groups of people.

He's a huge fan of both the Aboriginal memory techniques and the Memory Palace, so I think you're going to love how we discuss all the techniques we go over in this discussion.

As the author of Sand Talk: How Indigenous Thinking Can Save The World, Dr. Yunkaporta is an incredible teacher. I found this book compelling, useful and the main mnemonic device taught in the book is an obvious win for social change and healing global issues.

Because as Tyson expresses in this interview, the time for "memory wars" and all kinds of other wars is over. We simply don't have time for them anymore. And to help you in your culture be part of the solution, instead of the problem, you need to widen your context and bring that back into your community.

Here are just some of the memory techniques you'll discover in this discussion:

Real places and objects
Relational
Haptic connections
Riddles and wordplay
Night sky
Place and maps of place
Symbols and images
Rhythm and rhyme
Repetition
Song
Rude language
Stories
Message sticks

In sum, if you were to put these mnemonics into play, you'd be using them as a "way of life."

For more on the scientific study that inspired this "yarn," please see my discussion with Dr. David Reser:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UkDgT6_sNJQ

I also recommend you supplement this video with Brilliant Miller's interview with Tyson:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JCzlgBbv5OY

Lynne Kelly comes up in this interview, so if you'd like to catch up with me and her, please see:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jim_csNGV1Q

The "Memory Wars" recording with Dr. Reser and Dr. Yunkaporta:

https://anchor.fm/tyson-yunkaporta/episodes/Memory-Wars-e12c0em

We talk about a number of mnemonic devices in this interview, so please be prepared to write them down. Songlines are part of a larger set that people used who had a ton of knowledge they needed in order to survive. 

Make sure you supplement your own survival by digging as deeply as you can into the wide range of techniques history around the world has to offer. And apply the information you acquire to helping the world become a better place. 

Thanks for being part of the memory world at large and talk soon!

Sincerely,

Dr. Anthony Metivier

title: My Memory Palace Habits
description:
Do you want to incorporate the Memory Palace technique into your everyday life?

Whether it's for general memory improvement or for studying, I've done it all. 

And in this video, I take you behind the scenes. 

You might just call this video, "A Day in the Life of Anthony Metivier."

Of course, there's a lot more to things that I do than just the method of loci. 

I have to fit in writing, music practice, fitness, filming and all kinds of things. 

I imagine that you're much the same, so I hope you enjoy the tips that I share. 

If I were to boil it all down to one thing, it's this:

I LIVE inside a Memory Palace. 

And that makes all the difference in the world. 

I also don't take the easy way out, which so many do, which is why they struggle to improve their memory.

But if you're into the holistic memory training I talk about, please make sure to follow up with the additional resources I have to share. Memory is a martial art of the mind. And to experience its benefits, you have to treat it as such. 

Plus, you need to take the meditation and mindfulness angles seriously. 

So many people can't work out how to use this technique because they simply don't have quiet minds.

But when you learn to quiet the mind, all memory techniques become incredibly fun and much easier. 

Plus, learning to organize your day is hugely important. There's really no way to improve everything across the board if you live a life of chaos. 

Disruptions must be reduced so that you can focus on what matters. That was one of the points of focus I took you through in the video on image streaming I created for you a while back. Did you check it out? 

In all things, you can have an amazing memory. 

I'd love to help you out, so if you're new here, get subscribed, his that thumbs up and let me know your questions and progress updates in the comments. 

Sincerely, 

Dr. Anthony Metivier
https://www.magneticmemorymethod.com

title: Better Than The Memory Palace? | Deep Dive Into A Scientific Study With Dr. David Reser
description:
Dozens of people emailed me recently about some news articles stating that an Aboriginal memory technique is better than the Memory Palace. 

You know what?

It might just be. 

But our knowledge of how and why it might work requires nuanced understanding of what the study actually says - along with as many voices as we can get to help us explore it.

That's why I reached out to Dr. David Reser at Monash University. Here's his profile:

https://research.monash.edu/en/persons/david-reser

Dr. Reser on Twitter:

https://twitter.com/dreser_neuro

The original study:

https://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0251710

Follow-up interview with Tyson Yunkaporta:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=R_--IAZz410

From what I can understand, this study is incredibly interesting and bodes very well for future studies and your own application of the aboriginal memory technique. I can only hope more will emerge. 

In fact, I'm hoping to follow with a second interview with Tyson Yunkaporta. Until then, here's an existing interview with him about his book Sand Talk:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JCzlgBbv5OY

In brief, this study showed that the Aboriginal technique performed better than the Method of Loci after a certain period of time. Tests after longer periods of time had fewer participants, so it feels like the study is less conclusive until further data from future tests arrive.

There are several other factors this conversation brought out that bring nuance to the role of the participants and what their preparedness suggests. I think the role of terminology also comes through and it is an interesting opportunity to think through how and why terms emerge as such.

In all things, the Memory Palace technique for studying and anything else was always just a term. And anything that adds to our knowledge of how to memorize anything better, faster and with great joy should be embraced. I can't wait to learn more about this methodology, see future studies and give some of the ideas a try.

I hope this discussion helps you consider the role of science in discovery, the role of mind in learning and starts you on a deeper journey with all the memory traditions around the world.

title: Hyperphantasia: A Guided Meditation For Seeing In Your Mind | Memory-Based Meditation
description:
Can you experience hyperphantasia and start seeing in your mind? 

I believe so, and in this guided meditation, I want to help you boost your mind's eye.

The role of mental imagery is not well understood, but it is very well-experienced. The trick is to have some guidance in paying closer attention to your experience of consciousness. 

That way, you can experience visualization in many different ways.

Will this memory-based meditation help you if you have aphantasia, or just normal phantasia?

I believe so and here's why:

When I was a kid, they didn't use the term "aphantasia." They didn't even have such a thing as an aphantasia test. Instead, I was told I had "Imagination Deficit Disorder."

The consequences weren't so severe in my case because I'm a stubborn individual. I fought back and took the courses I wanted to take anyway. 

But others have been held back and that's why I created this guided meditation. I want you to succeed, and much more quickly than I did. 

To get the most out of this guided meditation experience, here are some suggestions:

1. It doesn't really matter if you have your eyes open or closed. You can experiment with both. 

2. Do your best to link your breath with the questions I ask throughout the meditation experience. 

3. Try to notice objections and then let them go. It's normal for the "monkey mind" to object, so just notice it and let it go. Use your breath.

4. Do your best to answer the questions I'm asking. You might not be used to thinking in this way, and that's fine. Give it your best and come back to it to deepen your experience. The more you work with this form of self-inquiry, the better and more nuanced results you'll get.

5. Journal about your experience. This form of self-observation will help increase your metaskills and deepen your connection to the goal of hyperphantasia. 

6. Share your comments in the discussion. 

7. Check out the additional resources below.

As always, if you haven't completed the MMM FREE Memory Improvement Kit, please consider doing so. It's a great way to activate your mind's eye, especially when it comes to the eight Magnetic Mode: The Spatial Mode.

https://www.magneticmemorymethod.com/yt

Please let me know if you have any questions and I'll get back to you a.s.a.p.

Thanks as always for your interest and support of this channel. Talk soon! :-)

Sincerely,

Dr. Anthony Metivier
"Memory Scientist"
Creator, Magnetic Memory Method

title: What is Memory-based Meditation? Intro to Types 1 & 2 for Better Memory
description:
When I wrote The Victorious Mind, I focused on just one type of memory-based meditation. 

Now the time has finally come to teach the second type of memory-based meditation. 

Like Type 1, Type 2 is based heavily on the Memory Palace technique. But in this case, it draws even more heavily on research by Dr. Tim Dalgleish.

In his research, Dalgleish has shown how using the Method of Loci (a.k.a the Memory Palace technique) can help reduce depression and symptoms from other issues, such as PTSD.

I covered this research in depth in a live stream. Feel free to watch the replay, which is called: 

Can the Memory Palace Technique Help Depression? [Memory Science Evidence]

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vs9UHz4pVuM

Not only has this approach to using the Memory Palace helped me personally, but it is bound to work.

And so I want to begin releasing a number of guided meditation videos on this channel.

First, in this video, I need to explain more about the differences between Type 1 and Type 2 memory-based meditation. 

I wanted to go into depth because this will be a new direction for the channel and I hope regular and new viewers will support the initiative. I have every reason to believe that this is the biggest contribution the Magnetic Memory Method initiative can bring to humanity. 

If the whole idea that memory training and meditation can go together is new to you, here's a video that breaks it down. It's called:

Mindfulness and Meditation for Better Memory

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kPMoUYiPYLk

This video is chapter two of The Victorious Mind audiobook and presents the key research and the reasons why I think Type 1 memory-based meditation works so well. To this day, I continue to practice both.

There is much to explore when it comes to Type 2, so I hope you'll find this introduction video informative and useful. 

My hope is that this approach gives you something more active and consequential to do. It should be an alternative to the "Memory Recall" videos that talk about binaural beats and the like.

Such as this kind:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UjetznvcIjc

There's no research that shows any such things work. 


But there's lots of research showing that techniques like I shared in this TEDx Talk work very well:

title: Concentration Meditation For Focus: 5 POWERFUL Concentration Exercises
description:
Do you have a hard time focusing and wonder if concentration meditation will help?

It will, but let me riddle you this first because, you know, definitions matter.

Have you ever asked, what is concentration, exactly?

When you think about the word concentration, what comes to mind?

It probably brings up images of someone super-focused. Maybe they‚Äôre reading a long and complex novel, studying for a big exam, or doing a task that involves being really careful.

Yes, those things might be involved, but not necessarily. So let‚Äôs start thinking about concentration by thinking about it as circles. 

Why? 

Because the word ‚Äúconcentration‚Äù comes from ‚Äúconcentric.‚Äù That means having a common center. 

Common with whom or with what?

Well, that‚Äôs where things start to get really interesting and the meditations for focus and concentration you‚Äôre about to discover will help you find the center of concentration and accelerate your ability to enter into deeply focused states at will.


These concentration exercises are powerful, but please keep going with the following resources and additional concentration meditation exercises.

description:

title: 5 Ways To Unlock The Memory Palace Secrets In The Memory Improvement Books Of Giordano Bruno
description:
Giordano Bruno wrote several useful memory improvement books.


But they can be puzzling, especially since he talked about the Memory Palace technique in different ways. 

For example, he released the "Mind Palace" from the so-called method of loci in a few different ways by using seals and other kinds of association. 


For more on these matters, please check out all the videos in our Art of Memory playlist on this channel:


https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLkZ2FGJhR5R9njWtWwRrkZKaq8j7OjDL3


I used to struggle to understand a lot of what Bruno was talking about, but then I started to try using techniques he favored, such as ars combinatoria or the art of combination. 


It is truly powerful and the more I read Bruno's Memory Palace books, the more my practice improves. 


I don't know exactly where you should start with Giordano Bruno's memory training material, but On the Shadows of the Ideas is possibly not ideal. 

I hope the suggestions and memory resources I give in this video give you some direction - and if you're already clear on Bruno, please help others by diving into the discussion. 


That gives all of us more clarity and is exactly what I believe Bruno would have use aspire to. After all, memory training isn't about us as individuals (in his pantheism, there really are no individuals as such). We improve our memory to help others because that is the right thing to do.

For a full review of The Hermetic Art of Memory that deepens this admittedly philosophical point, please see:


https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ArFTgRDIWo4



It is yet another excellent memory improvement book to add to your collection.


For the vision statement training, please see:


https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MFz31HpVkj0

Thanks as ever for the view and please let me know what you'd like to see covered next on this channel.

Sincerely, 

Dr. Anthony "Always Reading Memory Books" Metivier

title: 3 Ways Giordano Bruno Was WRONG About The Memory Palace Technique
description:
We all know and love Giordano Bruno for his incredible books on the Memory Palace technique.

But what many people don't realize about books like On the Shadows of the Ideas is that it has three big problems. 

And these problems have made it hard for many students of memory techniques to make the progress they could have if they knew about them.

You see, there is no such thing as the Giordano Bruno memory system. He's trying to teach you how to create your own mnemonic strategies.

Even better, he's trying to teach what is called ars combinatoria, or the art of combination. More on that incredible mnemonic device for you right here:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0cYDmaBXvJg

Once you understand these things, you will use the Memory Palace, Roman Room, Journey Method, Mind Palace or whatever you want to call it a LOT better. 

Then, you will also understand Bruno better too and correct more of the errors introduced by Frances Yates in The Art of Memory.


This problem is covered in more-depth in part one of The Art of Memory Playlist:


https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=k3GGcO5Cx3I

Why is this topic so important? 

Because on top of becoming a master of your memory, you also stand to connect deeper with your own consciousness. And that is what Bruno is ultimately all about.

title: The Memory Palace of Giordano Bruno: Ars Combinatoria or The Art of Combination
description:
Giordano Bruno devices over 30 different kinds of Memory Palace. Ars Combinatoria is just one, and it is very powerful.

Sometimes called The Combinator, this memory wheel is a mixture Memory Palace of his "seals" called The Field and The Tree. 

Seals are something we'll explain later in The New Art of Memory Playlist. If you're new here and need to catch up, you can start the series here:

https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLkZ2FGJhR5R9njWtWwRrkZKaq8j7OjDL3

To read the original text yourself, here's the Amazon link for Thirty Seals and The Seal of Seals, prepared in translation by Scott Gosnell:

https://www.amazon.com/Thirty-Seals-Giordano-Bruno-Collected-ebook/dp/B01MRVORB7/


Let me know in the comments if you give this "Decision Memory Palace" a try. Obviously, you will want to meet the "requirements" Giordano Bruno has in mind before the real results start kicking in, but I believe using these techniques can itself help get you there. 

Who was Giordano Bruno and what is a Memory Palace? 

Although you may have heard that he is a hermetic wizard and whatnot from Frances Yates, it is not clear that this was the case. I throw some nuance on the topic in this analysis of her book, The Art of Memory:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=k3GGcO5Cx3I

My thesis is that Bruno was simply a very good master of the Memory Palace technique and quite likely someone who experienced what we sometimes call "enlightenment."

If this is the case, the feelings he described as being achievable by anyone likely arrived because he trained his procedural memory through extensive memory practice and use of the method of loci.

He also used his memory to work on topics like math, physics and philosophy and seems to have started quite young. He lived from 1548 to 1600 when he was burned at the stake. 

This is a sad outcome, but fortunately many of his memory improvement books survived. We are very blessed to have them and I look forward to diving deeper into more of them in future videos.

To learn more about the Memory Palace technique, please see:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=l5-YrZhudPU

Don't forget to grab my FREE Memory Improvement Kit while you're there:

https://www.magneticmemorymethod.com/yt

title: How to learn Chinese: A Simple, 15-Step Guide
description:
If you're confused about how to learn Chinese, this video is designed to help you out.

Now, I've only passed Level III in Mandarin at the Confucius Institute. (It's based somewhat but not directly on HSK). Given the fact that I passed the final exam with a score of 99%, I think you'll get great value from my experiences.

‰∏≠Êñá is an exciting language, but people struggle with how to learn Mandarin for reasons that you can easily overcome. 

Chinese grammar is one of the easiest parts of the Chinese language, and we'll talk about that. But when it comes to beginner Chinese, I've found that just memorizing the vocabulary was the easiest for me, provided I did it using what is called the levels-of-processing effect. This is also known as the Big Five of Language Learning.

Tools I've found most helpful along the way include the Outlier Linguistics courses and Pleco add-on. You can grab them all here:

https://www.magneticmemorymethod.com/outlier-linguistics-resources

Conversations by Olly Richards:

title: Memory Strategies: 7 Shockingly EASY Ways to Remember More
description:
Imagine having memory strategies that make it easy to recall names, facts, presentations, or even entire books effortlessly.

What would you do with memory skills like that?

Pass exams with confidence, learn new skills faster, or navigate your career with a razor-sharp memory?

As you'll discover in this video, the secret isn‚Äôt just natural ability ‚Äî it‚Äôs mastering proven memory techniques. 

Whether you're a student, professional, or lifelong learner, the memory strategies you're about to discover will upgrade your brain power and help you achieve more with less effort. From spaced repetition and memory palaces to chunking information and mind mapping, you‚Äôll discover step-by-step methods to enhance your memory retention and cognitive skills.

üí° What You‚Äôll Learn:

‚úÖ Memory Training Essentials: Simple, science-backed techniques that anyone can master to dramatically improve memory.

‚úÖ Learning Methods That Work: Use strategies like note-taking techniques, chunking, and mental imagery to absorb and recall information faster.

‚úÖ Brain Training for Mastery: Build a ‚Äúcognitive reserve‚Äù to protect your brain against mental fatigue and improve memory performance over time.

‚úÖ The Power of Long-Term Projects: Learn why focusing on a single learning project can unlock your creativity and supercharge your mental strength.

‚úÖ Organize Your Mind Like a Library: Structure your memory using tools like the Dewey Decimal System to retain vast amounts of knowledge with ease.

üß† The Key Techniques You‚Äôll Be Able To Explore:

‚úÖ Memory Palaces: Harness the ancient art of visualizing information in specific locations to make recall effortless.

‚úÖ Chunking Information: Break down complex data into manageable pieces for better understanding and retention.

‚úÖ Mind Mapping: Use creative, nonlinear diagrams to visualize relationships between ideas and strengthen your learning process.

‚úÖ Spaced Repetition: Master the timing of reviews to lock information into long-term memory.

‚úÖ Note-Taking Strategies: Move beyond traditional methods to capture and recall information more effectively.

‚úÖ Design your own long-term learning project to sustain focus and deepen your knowledge over time.

‚úÖ Practice creating Memory Palaces for everyday tasks like remembering grocery lists or presentations.

‚úÖ Use mind mapping to organize your learning and connect ideas across disciplines.
Build your own chunking system to simplify and memorize complex data.

These strategies provide more than mere memory improvement‚Äî they positively transform your life. Whether you‚Äôre preparing for a big exam, mastering a new language, or aiming to excel in your career, these tools empower you to learn smarter, not harder. 

You‚Äôll develop a mental edge that lasts a lifetime, boosting confidence, productivity, and even your overall well-being.
