title: The Victorious Mind Audiobook Sample - New Memory Improvement Book By Anthony Metivier
description:
The Victorious Mind: How to Master Memory, Meditation and Mental Well-Being by Anthony Metivier. 

The Victorious Mind shows you: 

¬†‚Ä¢ The #1 thing that holds you back from accomplishing your memory improvement goals. 

‚Ä¢ The 3 BIG misunderstandings that prevent you, as a lifelong learner, from fulfilling your purpose and dreams.

‚Ä¢ 3 things you must do to ‚Äúget on purpose,‚Äù get lasting traction AND establish the mental peace that creates true focus for the rest of your life.

‚Ä¢ The EXACT steps I follow to build memory systems that have helped me learn everything needed to live a life of passion - and escape the horrible nightmare my mind used to imprison me in.

Reviews:

"As a life long student of the art memory, I've read my fair share of rehashed How to memory books; this is not one of them. As someone who has dealt with depression and anxiety since leaving the military, this book really hit home. Dr. Metivier takes you through a guided tour of his early life, the demons he faced, his process of overcoming them, and his journey in becoming the modern-day Giordano Bruno.
 
 I can not thank him enough for his part in my metamorphosis from a mentally beat up U.S. Vet to a top student in University."

- Adolfo Artigas

"I bought this book in hopes for some memory techniques and a good read. Instead, I was surprised to behold a Swiss Army knife of meditation, breathing, and memory skills wrapped in the warm blanket of human experience and fascinating autobiography. 

The writing is concise and to the point. Necessary for the teaching of time honored techniques and exercises, put here to a new focus. Memory and well being. Anthony reveals great vulnerability in telling his story through the sufferings and mishaps that plagued his past, but there is no , "poor me" syndrome in the tone of his writing. He writes sincerely, with an open heart, to help others avoid the detrimental mental states that limited his potential during his obvious suffering. 

He encourages you, step by step, leading you in exercises to avoid/alleviate the pitfalls he encountered. Inspired by the traditions of Zen Buddhism, Mindfulness, and the works of Gary Weber and Alan Watts, Anthony Metivier brings you lifetimes of meditation practices without you having to sit under a tree for eternity or stare at a wall for millennia. 

Where he really shines is in the memory exercises which are his expertise! Whether you have been using Memory Palaces for decades or are following along building your very first palace, he guides you thoughtfully into the powerful techniques which can transform your life. I found his candid tales through dangerous mental states inspiring and egoless. He did not make this book to huff and puff about highfalutin memory techniques. He draws you through his suffering and allows you to experience the grace of success within the handling of his own mental state with the exercises he bequeaths to you in this charming book. Come for the techniques, stay for the drama! You will not be disappointed."

- Christian Fitzharris

title: How to Remember the Planets For Making A Memory Palace
description:
If you want to know how to remember the planets, you're in luck because it's actually really easy and fun. 

You can use an acronym or an acrostic. 

But using the Memory Palace technique or method of loci is probably best. 

Why? 

Two reasons:

1. There is no perfect mnemonic for the order of the planets. 

2. Because then you're able to use the planets you memorized AS a Mind Palace for memorising more things in the future!

title: The Art of Memory: Frances Yates, Giordano Bruno And The Mnemonic Tradition
description:
The Art of Memory by Frances Yates is an incredible study of the memory techniques used by figures through history. 

From Giordano Bruno and Marsilio Ficino to John Dee, Ramon Llull, Martin Faulks and Nelson Dellis, The Art of Memory has been an incredible resource for thousands of people around the world. 

The only problem is... Yates is considered by many scholars to have been incorrect about so many of her ideas. She seems to have deeply misunderstood Bruno when it comes to hermeticism and that suggests she might be misguided by how he and others used the Memory Palace technique. 

What was Frances Yates misguided on?

Not only how the great memory masters used their Roman Rooms and the Journey Method, but they used these ancient mnemotechnics to achieve encyclopedic memory to establish a theory of everything. 

Bruno's creativity was immense, and his ability to help others develop principles of self education and personal transformation is profound. But it matters a great deal that we understand the true implications of what Bruno was really saying, especially in an era when neuroscience tells us so much about the human brain. 

The recent memory championship tradition is fantastic, but it has left so much of the rich philosophy inherent to the mnemonics behind. This playlist series intends to help restore the psychology and hermetic thinking behind memory "magic" to bring back the best of renaissance science as we use the internet as our common school of advanced study to helps us learn faster and remember more. 

Frances Yates was lucky to have found the Warburg Institute and we're lucky Aby Warburg created it. So many important texts were preserved and Frances Yates helps us explore their many ideas. 

Future videos will explore the role of Thomas Aquinas' Summa Theologica in memory training. 

We'll look into the Rhetorica Ad Herrenium and the Picatrix. In this series, I want to leave no stone unturned. Here's the link to the playlist for checking back as new videos are added:

https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLkZ2FGJhR5R9njWtWwRrkZKaq8j7OjDL3

For more videos on The Art of Memory and hermetic memory, please see:

title: How to Memorize a Textbook: A 10 Step Memory Palace Tutorial
description:
Want to know how to memorize a textbook? 

Remembering more from books is a fun and easy skill to develop. 

But, as with all things, a lot depends on your mindset, your setup and the clarity of your goals.

That‚Äôs why, in this video, you‚Äôll learn how to:

 ‚Ä¢ Correctly set your expectations of what the book will contain
 ‚Ä¢ Understand why you need to read the book (or if you actually need to!)
 ‚Ä¢ Quickly determine how much of the book you really need to read
 ‚Ä¢ Make a dedicated Memory Palace system to memorize the parts you really need
 ‚Ä¢ Learn¬†how to take notes from a textbook¬†onto index cards or flashcards, and¬†
 ‚Ä¢ Determine how much time you‚Äôll need to practice the information you‚Äôve memorized

You'll learn how to memorize verbatim too.

Plus, I'm giving you an example of how to memorize a formula, the kind you might come across in a math textbook. 

Ultimately, what we're talking about when discussing textbook memorization is how to study books for maximum retention.

And retention is not necessarily memorization. It's important to understand that difference. 

And the Memory Palace technique you'll discover in this video is designed to make sure that you know how to get the most out of your study time.

title: Magnetic Memory Method Student Wins 2019 Canadian Memory Championship
description:
Many memory competitors have asked me if the Magnetic Memory Method Masterclass will help them win a memory competition. 

Normally, I tell them... "maybe, but I can't say for sure."

All that changed in 2019 when memory athlete James Gerwing won the Canadian Memory Championships. 

I've always known the MMM would help anyone use memory techniques better because I did pretty well myself when I competed. But I didn't win and can only say "yes" when someone else who uses this approach has.

And, of course, James has done a lot more than just competing. Year's ago, he wrote to me:

"I have been banging things into the void of my memory for decades.

You have revived, and revived in me, the concept that where there is a will, there is a way.

Since signing up for your Masterclass I have taken a Latin course at the University of Alberta and scored above 90% (that is not common territory for me)!"

As you'll discover in this video, one thing he said, let to this follow-up a few years later:

"Anthony, Jim Gerwing, here. About 5 years ago, I began taking your online course and then went into some memory competitions. I am the 4 time, current, undefeated (and record holder) of the Alberta memory championships. Even better; I just won the 2019 Canadian Memory Championships (AND the first ever pan-provincial championship). Thanks for your input.


Since signing up for your Masterclass I have taken a Latin course at the University of Alberta and scored above 90% (that is not common territory for me)!"

- James Gerwing, Educational administrator, Sherwood Park, Alberta (and now 2019 Canadian Memory Champion!"

In this video interview, you'll learn how the Magnetic Memory Method helped James win and discover how you can use these techniques to learn and memorize anything you want.

title: Advanced Language Learning Memory Tips With Ash Henson of Outlier Linguistics
description:
Learning a foreign language? 

There's no doubt about it. The process can present struggles. 

But the good news is that memory techniques like the Memory Palace and even just the basics of mnemonic association can help you break through every obstacle. 

On today‚Äôs Magnetic Memory Method video interview, I talk with the CTO, co-founder, and chief researcher of Outlier Linguistics, Ash Henson. 

A former electrical engineer for NASA, he discovered his love for languages in 1991, and left his high profile career to devote his life to language learning and teaching in 2004.

Since then he has received his PhD candidacy in both teaching Chinese as a second language, and has completed studies in paleography and phonology, as well as in-depth studies in classic Chinese literature.

Ash sheds light on what you really need to learn a language, the keys to master your target language (specifically whatever mastery means to you) in less time than you thought possible. Fluency is well within your grasp, and all it takes is a willingness to learn and openness to discover a different way of learning that‚Äôs highly possible, and probably a little foreign, but personal and proven to work.

Dive into this interview and you will discover: 

- The secret way rules can unlock thousands of words in your target language

- How sharing a cultural heritage can help make language learning easier

- When copying someone else is allowed, and even encouraged!

- Why you should be skeptical of native speakers‚Äô pronunciation advice, and when to just ‚Äútake their word for it.‚Äù

- How meaning and sound patterns help you to recall Chinese characters (this also applies to Japanese Kanji in many ways).

-  The reason you should learn to speak in your target language first, followed by writing

- Why making memory objects personal is the key to success with character memorization

- Reasons to NOT have a ‚Äúdedicated memory system‚Äù

- The reason ‚Äúspecifics‚Äù are important, i.e., the purpose of kinesthetic, auditory, and visual senses, and emotions in memory objects

- The purpose of specialized lists, such as animals, friends & family, and celebrities

- The importance of existing competence in your language learning journey and how climbing Mt. Everest is quite similar to tackling your target language goals

To learn more about Ash's work, check out:

https://www.outlier-linguistics.com/

Learn to Read Chinese Characters:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wkrUrzdqZyY

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=S8vmVJP9AAY

Enjoy this interview and let us know in the comments if you have any questions!

Dr. Anthony Metivier

title: COPPA: How Would Giordano Bruno And Fred Rogers Teach Memory Techniques in 2020?
description:
It's rare that I release videos about matters like the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act (COPPA), or "rule" as the FTC calls it. 

But it seems like these rules are overreaching... especially when it comes to the teaching of memory techniques. 

After all, in order to use association and Memory Palaces, we refer to all kinds of pop culture references that appeal to and have relevance for all age groups. 

Plus, we've seen these kinds of initiatives before... indeed, approximately 100 years ago. They didn't lead to the intended places... far from it. 

And the places things went led to events like Fred Rogers appearance before the Senate. 

And earlier than that... the burning of Giordano Bruno at the stake. 

You might not think old Fred Rogers has a lot to do with mnemonics and ye olde Memory Palace technique, but he does. 

And he always will, as long as those of us who use these techniques use the Major System and arrive at "mail" for 35. What better way to make that word concrete than by using a character from Mr. Rogers' imagination? 

This is how association works, and it doesn't matter what age you are and where you live - and all the ideals Fred Rogers fought so hard to ensure are directly involved in the Magnetic Memory Method initiative even though he and I never met. 

Under these new rules, there's really no way to share Giordano Bruno's memory system as I had planned. It needs updating and pop cultural references will make more sense than constellations to a modern audience. 

If you were me... what would you do? What do you think Bruno and Rogers would do if there were with us in 2020? 

Write the Senate and Congress and let them know after you post in the discussion area below. 

Let me know your thoughts in the discussion and thanks as always for your engagement with these videos and for sharing this one around.

title: How to Study and Remember | Part One: Foundational Study Tips
description:
If you wish someone would show you how to study and remember effectively, this first video in our new series is loaded with foundational learning and memory tips. 

You see, it's not just about mnemonics like the Memory Palace, Journey Method, or method of loci. 

If you want to study effectively, you also need to have a vision and a plan that let's you constantly focus on the key points of the topic at hand. 

Why should you take my word for it? 

Well, I've got a PhD and two MAs, for one thing - and I NEVER would have been able to do it without memory techniques. 

You see, I suffered terrible depressions while in grad school. Not only that, but I didn't think very highly of myself and had CRUSHINGLY low self-esteem. 

But memory training helped me get my brain in order. It helped me focus and concentrate - even when times were tough and I still didn't feel well. 

I've been doing so much better ever since, and now it is my MISSION to help as many people as possible learn and use these same techniques. 

Are they challenging? 

Yes, sometimes - but that's part of how they help elevate your mood as you literally CONQUER information. 

Of course, no one can use the techniques for you, so make sure you've got a strong enough vision. You'll find a video all about creating proper and effective vision statements for learning faster here: 

https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLkZ2FGJhR5R8H3hdOzzg4VicSYZfutRyb

title: Iconic Memory Defined And Why Photographic Memory DOES NOT Exist
description:
Iconic memory is a powerful type of sensory memory that helps you recall visual stimuli for brief moments.

In this video, we‚Äôll explore the difference between iconic memory and photographic memory, debunking myths about picture-perfect recall.

You'll also learn how iconic memory compares to echoic memory and how it connects to your short-term and long-term memory. Finally, we'll dive into groundbreaking research by George Sperling and others to uncover the science behind visual persistence.

If you‚Äôve ever wondered how to improve your memory, strengthen your attention, and build Memory Palaces, this video is for you! Don‚Äôt forget to visit magneticmemorymethod.com/iconic-memory for additional resources, and watch until the end to learn actionable memory improvement tips that can change your life.

Iconic memory also explains why images disappear from our minds in a flash. But it's not photographic memory, even if it affects short term and long term memory. In this video, we‚Äôll explore why. 

It‚Äôs also different than other kinds of memory and we‚Äôll talk about an echoic memory example to explain why. Auditory memory can also comes in flashes, but iconic memory is much more related to flashbulb memory in many key ways.

The neat thing about this kind of memory is how it relates to at least 3 kinds of persistence in human memory related to visual, haptic and subjective cues. 

If you‚Äôre interested in knowing more about visual memory, the visual system of the brain, working memory related to visual stimuli and more, please check out the full article with all the references on the Magnetic Memory Method website:

https://www.magneticmemorymethod.com/iconic-memory/

Your memory almost certainly has unlimited capacity to learn, and so I look forward to exploring more of its psychophysics over the course of time. 

If you need ideas for what to work on next, check out these sensory memory exercises:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2rUi7LNPHSA

Thanks for sharing this one around and talk soon! :-)

Sincerely, 

Anthony Metivier

title: How to Get Out Of Your Comfort Zone For Better Memory Training
description:
A lot of people who come to memory training never get anywhere. 

Why? 

Because they get stuck in their comfort zone. 

There are memory comfort zones examples I could give, but I think you know what I mean:

You start a new memory improvement course or book and feel excited. And then...

After trying a few things... 

You completely slump and get trapped in what amounts to the "chains" of your procedural memory...

Doing everything exactly the same way you did it yesterday...

And getting nowhere as a results. 


Well, today that changes.

title: Martin Faulks on the Memory Palace in the Masonic Tradition
description:
Martin Faulks is the author of A Mosaic Palace and is a memory expert who has performed a number of interesting demonstrations. 

A Mosaic Palace is also a great book. I highly recommend it in addition to this talk. You can find it here:

https://www.lewismasonicdigital.com/ebooks/general/a-mosaic-palace/

Who is Martin Faulks? 

In addition to being a memory expert, he is an expert in the field of meditation. 

On top of that, he‚Äôs a martial artist, yoga teacher, and author of over half a dozen books on subjects such as enlightened living and tai chi.

His newest book, A Mosaic Palace: Freemasonry and the Art of Memory explores the link between the ancient tradition of memory techniques and the secretive fraternal organization, the Freemasons.

In our conversation we explore memory as an internal transformative art that can change the very core of our being just in dedicated practice. 

He argues that while in antiquity inner transformation through memory was a common association, but it has been lost in our modern age. The secret then to restoring this idea lies in your approach to committing to the techniques themselves.

Our talking points in this video interview include:

* Memory training and the potential for learning leading to inner transformation (and how what you put into your consciousness can change who you are)

* How the Renaissance caused the art of memory to become a path of cultivation of virtue instead of simply utilitarian

* How Memory Palaces are useful as a form of meditation

* The impact of adaptive strategies on our personality and coping and life skills

* The way your mind is always trying to help you

* The method in which you learn something affects how easy it is for you to reference it

* Why the church banned texts like the Ars Notoria as a ‚Äúsorcery version of memory‚Äù

* How the memory method of corporeal similitudes is the most powerful way to create associations for memory

* The debate about whether Sherlock Holmes is a figure to look up to (otherwise known as a hero of an extra level of functioning) to when it comes to memory goals

* Comparing and contrasting memory and sorcery, and memory palaces and magic circles

* Why Giordano Bruno was a memory master and ‚Äúterrible‚Äù teacher

* The differences in the definition of a memory master according to various cultures


How to find more of Martin Faulks on the Web:

Website:

https://martinfaulks.co.uk/

Twitter:

https://twitter.com/MartinFaulks

YouTube Channel:

https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCt8UUqwAccfhetgC7alponA

title: Why Memory Apps Do NOT Improve Short Term Memory And the REAL Memory Exercise You Need
description:
If you want to improve short term memory, the only reasonable path is to get REAL memory exercise. 

And yes, I mean it when there's little evidence that any Memory Palace software of memory improvement app is ever going to help anyone even remotely as well as some people have claimed. 

Now, some people are going to run kicking and screaming from the notion that we're on our own when it comes to getting the mental fitness in that we need. But in this video, I'll be sharing some easy, fun and incredibly simple ways to get more mental fitness. 

I'm also sharing some great book references that back up my claims and some articles that show the potential for some huge nightmares we all face if we don't take care of our brains. 

There are 3 memory exercises in total and I'm convinced that if you put them into action, you'll experience a boost in your memory.

I also share the secret of "elaborative encoding" and show you how to do it using a simple set of mnemonic examples. You can do complete these exercises with or without a Memory Palace.)

But if you want to use the Memory Palace technique and don't know what it is, start with this playlist on what a Mind Palace is and why the term you use (Memory Palace vs. Mind Palace) matters:

https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLkZ2FGJhR5R_mzDp76DZH5n5mG-ni72LC

Look, I can go on and on in this description about why short term memory boosts are possible, but aren't you better off watching this video in full? 

Here's what will happen when you do:

* I'll teach you how to never forget where you placed your keys again

* I'll give you 3 POWERFUL memory exercises that improve ALL aspects of your memory

* I'll give you a number of powerful book references that will help you even further (if you want to TRULY get ahead in life)

Isn't that fair for achieving lasting brain power? 

Enjoy this video and these resources mentioned in Part Two of this playlist. Part Three is coming soon! :-)

A lot of people ask: How can I improve short term memory? 

Well, it's an interesting question... but also the wrong question. 

You see, "short term memory" is a scientific term, and the terminology of memory science (as in all science) is always expanding. 

In this video, you'll learn the real path to short term memory loss treatment by approaching all memory holistically. 

It has nothing to do with short term memory supplements. There's no test or short term memory game that will help. 

What you need is the same thing the ancients used to memorize entire books and structure their minds. This approach truly is the best way to learn faster and remember more.

title: Method of Loci Q&A: How Often Should You REPEAT Information in a Memory Palace?
description:
The method of loci is by far the best study method on the planet. But when learning to use a Memory Palace based on this ancient memory technique, many people ask:

How often should you repeat the information on your loci (or Magnetic Stations)? Are there "repetition rules" when it comes to spaced repetition?

This is an important consideration when you're learning how to study using memory techniques, especially sophisticated mnemonics. 

For more on the Method of Loci, please see these 9 Powerful Memory Palace Training tips:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7tNZZEt83Jw

In your Mind Palace Practice, the exact answer to the question does not exist, but this video gives you the best practices you need to consider in order to get the best results.

https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLkZ2FGJhR5R85djoWQcvmQLxfO-ipHgQ5

title: 3 WORST Memory Training Tips From Memory Experts
description:
If you've spent any time looking for memory training tips, you've probably come across some bad suggestions. 

These are 3 of the worse I've ever seen. And what makes the so bad is that they come from people who call themselves memory experts. 

That is truly disappointing. 

These people mean well, but they're not only give memory training techniques a bad name, but also hurting the students who need these memory techniques the most. 

And if you're looking for memory training exercises, these points of advice rob you of the progress you deserve. You'd be better off playing a memory training game and facing the consequences of digital amnesia.

title: Remembering Poems: Memory Training Discussion with Christian Fitzharris
description:
Remembering poems is fun and easy. Today we'll talk about exactly how to do it. 

Even better, Christian Fitzharris shares some classic poems to memorize that you'll likely want to memorize too. 

Are all poems worth memorizing?

title: 3 Ways To Give RELAXED Memory Demonstrations [The Ultimate Memory Palace Training Exercise]
description:
Once you've learned memory techniques, you'll probably want to give memory demonstrations. 

And even if you don't want to give them - you should. 

For one thing, it's really the only short term memory test that will give you the feedback you need to determine where your memory skills stand. 

And you want to give yourself a working memory test as often as possible - memory demonstrations are the best way to do that. 

This form of Memory Palace training can take a few different forms, so in this video I share some of my experiences, including how I relax myself so that I'm never nervous.

title: 3 Blazing Fast Ways To Increase Memory Retention
description:
Memory retention... what the heck is it? Is it worth worrying about? If so, can it be improved? 

Overall, it's quite simple to define:

It is the ability to keep any information for different periods of time for the purpose of using it in the future. 

And so if someone gives you their name, but you can't use their name in a conversation, you haven't retained it. 

Why exactly we retain some things and not others is the subject for another video, but basically, we don't really need a definition more robust than this. 

But you might be wondering about the differences between short term memory and long term memory when it comes to memory retention. 

You might even be wondering about how working memory plays into the mix when it comes to learning faster and remembering more. 

These are all great questions, along with the biggest of them all:

Why is memory retention important? 

Dive into this video and get my FREE Memory Improvement Kit at:

https://www.magneticmemorymethod.com/yt

In short, improve your memory with memory techniques and you will automatically improve your memory retention.

SO addictive but are they worth our time? We now live in a world where technological advancements have made things SUPER convenient for us! But to what extent do memory improvement games really help us and our cognitive function? 

Most of the time, I hear people say ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt need to bother with remembering this now, I have a phone‚Äù or ‚Äútechnology was invented for a reason‚Äù. There are many arguments for and against these brain games, which is why the whole thing seems to be a controversial topic. For that reason, I decided to make a video about the truth behind these memory improvement apps. 

As I suggest in this video, the best mind games have nothing to do with brain game apps. In fact, there are many many ways to improve your memory ORGANICALLY. While digital memory improvements can offer some marginal benefits, there aren‚Äôt that many research to support this. 

I wholeheartedly believe that these games are not what they say they are, and I can prove that there are much better ways and better tips for memory improvement that do not rely on these brain games. Your memory is improved when you train, apply and use the information that improves your life. This is the challenge needed to REALLY improve your memory and concentration instead of playing games out of convenience. I have dedicated my life into creating awareness regarding this fact which is why I came up with a memory improvement tool that would hopefully help us all. AND IT‚ÄôS COMPLETELY FREE!

For my FREE Memory Improvement Kit that will show you the real challenge of memory so you can learn any language fast, memorize complex terminology and even entire discographies of lyrics, go here now: 

https://www.magneticmemorymethod.com/yt

On that note, I mentioned a few techniques from this kit in this video to make memory improvement easier for everyone without ANY ASSISTANCE! I made is as fun and easy as I could! In fact, I even gave a few examples that helps me when applying these memory TECHNIQUES which would hopefully help you as well :) 

REMINDER: your brain is sharp! This video is mainly about being prepared to perform, no matter what happens in your life. Turn your challenge into something that can improve your life! Keep calm and remember, your mind is sharp and it has the potential to achieve many things to improve your life if you would just allow it to work ;) 

Sincerely, 

Anthony Metivier

https://www.magneticmemorymethod.com

title: Why I Only Read Physical Books Instead Of Digital Ebooks
description:
I got tired of reading ebooks about two years ago. Partly due to concerns about Digital Amnesia, partly because I wasn't achieving my memory improvement goals. 

And since my goals is in always learning more about how to learn faster and remember more, I make sure that I can one:

1. Index the material better in my mind

2. Reference and re-reference while reading

3. Keep the books visible

4. Use reading to practice Digital Fasting

5. Remember page numbers and details

6. Assimilate reading into my life

7. Demonstrate the values and virtues of reading from real books and remembering as much as possible from them

Of course, all of these steps work best when used in combination with a Memory Palace. Learn how by getting my FREE Memory Improvement Kit here:

https://www.magneticmemorymethod.com/yt

title: Critical Thinking And Memory Improvement On Tap E01S01: The Fist
description:
Critical thinking is a skill that involves memory improvement in many aspects. 

It also requires the practice of long form discussion to improve your attention span. 

Why? 

Because long form discussion is the single most powerful of all the critical thinking exercises. 

Thanks to William Gordon of http://williamgordon.com.au/ for suggesting this discussion and holding it. 

In addition to "the fist" memory technique, we talk about: 

Joe Rogan and News Radio
Dave Foley and Kids in the Hall
Lorne Michaels and Saturday Night Live
The Simultaneous Sip
Friedrich Nietzsche and The Gay Science, Beyond Good And Evil, Also Sprach Zarathustra
Michel Foucault and What is an Author? 
Sam Harris and Waking Up
Jordan Peterson on the Waking Up Podcast
Empiricism
Gary Weber and Happiness Beyond Thought, Evolving Beyond Thought
James Swartz and The Essence of Enlightenment, The Fire of Self-Knowledge (Atma Bodha)
David Hume (not Edmund Burke)
The Ugly Sister Effect

https://www.magneticmemorymethod.com/beginners-guide-to-overcoming-the-ugly-sister-effect/

Advaita Vedanta and self-inquiry as the ultimate tool of critical thinking

And of course, you can use memory techniques while practicing the art of critical thinking. One of the goals of this new playlist is to simply demonstrate searching through memory out loud while engaged in critical thought. 

For next time, we're both going to read this article to pick up during our next discussion:

http://www.d.umn.edu/~cstroupe/handouts/8906/Foucault_what_is_an_author.pdf

Please read it too if you want to join us in the comments on the next critical thinking video. 

Share your critical thoughts in the discussion and for FREE Memory Improvement training, visit:

https://www.magneticmemorymethod.com/yt

Sincerely, 

Anthony Metivier

title: Zillions of Facts! | Defeat Memory Overwhelm | Memory Improvement Hangout
description:
Free webinar on the best discipline and consistency tools and tips that helped me get a PhD, have a great memory and build a business: 

https://www.magneticmemorymethod.com/dc

Why am I doing this webinar? 

Well, this recent cry of desperation from Larry nearly broke my heart.

He said‚Ä¶

"How can the Magnetic Memory Method work in internal medicine where there are 3 Zillion facts?"

You see, when I was studying at university, I used to get overwhelmed and say similar things too‚Ä¶

I‚Äôd read the great philosophers and wonder how I would ever catch up to the hundreds of books they had read. 

And in moments of desperation, I would think... ¬†I wasn't "one of those people" who get to be professors because there was no way I could read so much so fast‚Ä¶

Worse, I thought I wasn't gifted with a great memory.

In fact, I nearly failed out of grad school because of it.

We had these big end-of-year exams for the language requirement. We were required to read ‚Äì and I'm not exaggerating ‚Äì a couple hundred books. And then the professors would grill us on them for 2 to 3 hours straight.

Worst part was‚Ä¶

I'd study for hours and hours. And at the end of it all‚Ä¶ I couldn't remember a darned thing.

It was around that time that I stumbled upon a few basic memory techniques.

And to my great surprise‚Ä¶

I could do them!

In that moment, it hit me that my problem had nothing to do with a "bad memory". My mind wasn't somehow "faulty" or "broken".

And, if I just used the right approach‚Ä¶

I really could read and remember hundreds of books.

Even better, I could tap into a hidden potential of my brain that I had no idea even existed‚Ä¶ a capacity to remember anything and everything I wanted to.

In fact, I even stunned my professors (and myself) by acing my finals.

Now, I understand this all may sound a bit hard to believe. And you might also be thinking that it‚Äôs impossible in a field of knowledge with 3 Zillion facts.

Well, we all know that exaggeration is usually our worst enemy. And that's why I'm putting together something incredibly exciting and powerful for you‚Ä¶ 

Something that will allow you to personally try out the method I used‚Ä¶ and experience the hidden potential of your own mind for yourself. Without letting exaggeration get in the way of your success.

It‚Äôs well known by tens of thousands around the world that I‚Äôve got something that will help you memorize nearly ANYTHING you want in just a couple months. (And have perfect recall too.)

But I'm not ready yet to show you how you can remove the feeling of overwhelm that comes from within. I can‚Äôt speak for Larry, and I‚Äôm certainly not saying he‚Äôs exaggerating because I don‚Äôt know. Maybe there are world class doctors who really have memorize 3 Zillion facts. But I doubt that‚Äôs true or necessary in anyone‚Äôs field. I just know that I‚Äôve felt this way too. And the right memory techniques are the cure. ¬†

I'm still putting the final touches on it, so watch your inbox on Monday, July 23, 2018.

Now‚Ä¶

To prepare for next week, I want you to do a quick exercise for me.

Try and remember the last time you felt overwhelmed. How did you describe it? 

And if you could get past those limiting inner beliefs and exaggerations I managed to overcome and had a "flawless" memory‚Ä¶ one where you could rapidly (and effortlessly) absorb new information and recall it perfectly the moment you needed it‚Ä¶

What would you do?

What would having that kind of memory let you accomplish?

Maybe you'd finally become fluent in that new language you've been wanting to learn. Maybe you'd be able to ace difficult exams for school or for your profession. Or maybe you'd memorize long passages of scripture and deepen your faith.

Even if it seems like an "impossible dream" to you right now, write it down anyway. 

There's no right or wrong answer here, even if there are right and wrong ways of dealing with overwhelm. 

OK, talk soon.

Sincerely,

Anthony Metivier
"Memory Scientist"
Creator, Magnetic Memory Method


P.S. Could you do me a favor? Would you mind sharing both your description of frustration and seemingly ¬†"impossible dream" with me? (Just reply to this email.)

This will help me tailor my big plans for next week to your specific memory goals and better help you remove the ‚Äúoverwhelm monster‚Äù that might be holding you back.

P.P.S. If you enjoyed this video on memory training and mnemonic memory techniques, please help others by adding some captions.

description:

But the question is: 

Can you really extend your attention span?

title: Digital Amnesia: 5 Ways To Stop Google From Ruining Your Memory
description:
Are you aware that using digital devices deteriorates your memory through a degrading process called Digital Amnesia?

Sounds scary, right? 

It is and rest assured: it would be really frustrating to have your information faded into oblivion.

Not even using a Memory Palace for studying can stop it!  

This condition of forgetting things due to the advent of technology is often called something worse: ‚ÄúDigital Dementia‚Äù. 

This may be your first time to hear these terms. And you might be asking, ‚ÄúWhat exactly is ‚ÄúDigital Amnesia‚Äù?

Good question. Here‚Äôs the answer in full on the Magnetic Memory Method Podcast and blog:

https://www.magneticmemorymethod.com/digital-amnesia/

Digital Amnesia occurs whenever your mind draws a blank on the information you‚Äôve stored on a device you trust. You save bookmarks on your browser and you never visit them again. 

Does that ever happen to you? 

Whenever you stored an information to your digital devices and you place it somewhere, your mind draws a blank. Aren‚Äôt you tired of drawing blanks? More often than not, you can‚Äôt even remember what it was that you stored there. That said, you are experiencing Digital Amnesia. 

You‚Äôre weakening your brain because you are developing a dependence on technology. People are not remembering phone numbers, passwords and other significant information. 

The reason is that they let their dumbphones do the work. They are not aware that they are making themselves dumber and endangering their memory in the long run.

description:
Would you like to know how to increase memory power by yoga? 

Well... we had better start with a fuller definition of "yoga." Because when it comes to increasing your brain power and memory power and using activities like yoga for concentration...

It's not just about movement. To experience the fullest benefit of what some call super brain yoga exercise, you're going to need to do more than that. 

But the good news is that yoga really is a great way to get more from mnemonics. Yoga for concentration and memory combines well with the Memory Palace technique if you apply the two memory improvement exercises in particular ways. 

Meditation for concentration and memory also plays a role, and the Mind Palace approach does wonders when using a Memory Palace for studying.

title: A Quick, Powerful Memory Palace Exercise in 2 Stages
description:
Looking for a quick Memory Palace exercise? 

This video gives you one the best, easiest and fastest Memory Palace exercises you perform almost every day. Memory improvement exercises like this don't just arrive on your plate every day, so dive in and give this one a try. 

Of all the memorization techniques, the Memory Palace (sometimes called the Mind Palace) remains amongst the best. 

And if you want to transcend the need for mnemonic examples that hold others back when they're learning how to memorize vocabulary words fast, this exercise will ensure that you never suffer "Memory Palace Scarcity." 

Sound like a made-up condition? 

Perhaps. 

But in all the years I've been teaching memory improvement and memory techniques through mnemonics and regular memory exercise, Memory Palace Scarcity is a real problem people face.

And the exercise in this video is a major cure. 

So whether you need a Memory Palace foreign language strategy or a Memory Palace for studying STEM strategy, this exercise will help. 

Dive in, let it help you experience real, meaningful and lasting memory improvement and give your memory the royal treatment it deserves with my FREE Memory Improvement Kit by clicking over to:

title: Aphantasia: Develop Your Memory Even If You Cannot See Mental Images
description:
Have you come across aphantasia and wondered why you can't visualize? 

What about your mind's eye? Do you believe you don't have one? 

If so, this video will reveal the truth about mental imagery and visualization. 

And this is IMPORTANT if you have aphantasia. My friend Gerrard Gosens is congenitally blind and still figured out a way to visualize information he needed to memorize. Check out our discussion about it there:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-930UmWv1FI

His story will help you and here's why:

Because if we all want to get better at creating mental images, we need to understand what they really are and how they relate to memory improvement and the Memory Palace technique that can make so much positive change to your ability to learn. 

Making mental images couldn't be easier. But if you've ever said, "I can't visualize things in my head," you've probably felt frustrated. 

Actually, I never was frustrated, as you can hear me discuss in this interview with AphantasiaMeow:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=k0F9gOgGOqc

It seems I might even be on the brink of hyperphantasia!

But you really can make some bold actions. You can improve your memory and concentration. And you can use memorization techniques, the Method of Loci, the Memory Palace technique, Mind Palace technique and anything and everything that uses mental imagery. 

And you really cannot fail because mental imagery - properly understood - will increase your brain power. It will give you brain exercise. Your mental imagery psychology inner experience will shift and you will articular your ideas much, much better. 

Here are some links that will help you further if you have - or have been told you have - aphantasia. 

First, here's my full post and podcast on aphantasia:

https://www.magneticmemorymethod.com/aphantasia/

Use it to supplement my FREE Memory Improvement Kit:

https://www.magneticmemorymethod.com/yt

You'll also want to check out my first video on aphantasia and read through the discussion posts:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2l1DJXZyHmM

Here's my 2019 aphantasia cure update:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=y0Z88TSKejw

Then check out Blake Ross and his post on Aphantasia: 

https://www.facebook.com/notes/blake-ross/aphantasia-how-it-feels-to-be-blind-in-your-mind/10156834777480504/

This post might not help you with mental imagery and visualization, but it's useful for expanding your awareness of this topic:

http://www.nytimes.com/2015/06/23/science/aphantasia-minds-eye-blind.html?_r=0

AphantasiaMeow is also doing great work with helping people discover how to experience having a mind's eye:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LA0ZUj7Wtmc&lc=

AphantasiaMeow Website for help with aphantasia and an aphantasia test: www.aphantasiameow.com

Here's Jonathan Levi on the topic:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6n_KyqrPriQ

There are many more links to follow up on related to this issue. I hope you will enjoy exploring the topic and find freedom from the "diagnosis" if you've been given it. 

Summing up: Love your mind and your brain as it is! 

Much love and respect from the Magnetic Memory Method Headquarters. 

Sincerely, 

Anthony Metivier
https://www.magneticmemorymethod.com

P.S. Subscribe to this channel for more memory improvement and Memory Palace tips: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCdIwC3d4CRjrrQdaqZaNBpA

P.P.S. If you enjoyed this video on memory training and mnemonic memory techniques, please help others by adding some captions.

description:

https://www.magneticmemorymethod.com/tansel-ali/

title: Is Coconut Oil Effective For Memory Improvement? (Coconut Oil Debunked?)
description:

I can't say that coconut oil has helped with with anxiety and depression either, but it has helped in other ways.

title: How To Use Quora Better And Get The Best Quora Answers
description:
If you're wondering how to use Quora better and get the best Quora answers, we really all need to get together and start asking better questions. 

Whom am I to judge? 

I'm someone consistently pegged to answer questions about memory improvement by people around the world. 

And I'm honored. 

But the Google Effect, a.k.a. Digital Dementia a.k.a. Digital Amnesia have really led to an issue where people are asking for hand outs without even trying to answer the questions themselves first. 

And that means low quality answers by default.  In other words, you won't get any answers even worth using the Memory Palace technique with, nor the method of loci, nor much else beyond people reaching and grasping after this and that on quora.com

In sum:

1. When asking questions, be specific as possible

2. Then , before reaching out, try to answer it as much as you possibly can on your own

3. Document the journey of answering the question

4. Analyze the data you gather

5. Implement and take action on ideas where appropriate

6. Seek out insights from specialists based on specialized questions that come from your experiences in steps 1‚Äì5

7. Study constantly throughout the process and find communities that specialize in the area who can discuss angles with. 

But understand that they can only help you shed light on dark areas by seeing the light you‚Äôve shone yourself.

For more on how this works, incorporate the W.R.A.P. Technique. It‚Äôs discussed in depth here:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MxWLhAeIYOU 

There may be other steps that you need to follow, but without specific questions, I‚Äôm afraid that most experts cannot help you.

title: Free Tickets To Memory Games @ Skillcon in Las Vegas
description:

https://www.eventbrite.com/e/the-sin-city-memory-games-skillcon-tickets-39456644887

Sponsored by BrainHackers.com and hosted by a mystery celebrity as part of an ESPN Multi-sport: 

The Sin City Memory Games is a fun and educational memory sport that challenges experienced players with head-to-head competition and also teaches new participants how to unleash their natural photographic memory.
 
Learn the secrets of memory and compete for prizes in this exciting and challenging brain game!
 
On Dec. 16th, students, professionals, memory amateurs, and memory record holders from all over the world will come together in Las Vegas for the Sin City Memory Games at SkillCon. 
 
This event is OPEN to the public! Registration includes the SkillCon pass that gives you access to over 25 other events like juggling, dodgeball, STEAM (Science, Technology, Engineering, Arts, Math) education, and more!
 
It's challenging for experienced memory athletes but participant-friendly as it includes full training in the art of memorization for new players with support materials, so everyone can feel what it‚Äôs like to achieve a superhuman memory.
 
Before each round, there will be a mini-seminar/workshop on memory techniques for that specific game. 2x Guinness Record Holder for Greatest Memory, Dave Farrow, will show participants how to get 3x the average score on memory tests, memorize a deck of playing cards, and easily recall numbers, names, and faces.
 
Practice your new skills and challenge yourself to a friendly and fun competition among peers! Farrow Memory Tournaments pit competitors against each other in head-to-head matchups where perfection is the goal. Even one mistake can lose the match so it is exciting to participate in and fun to watch!

***
ABOUT DAVE FARROW, EVENT FACILITATOR:
Dave Farrow earned his second Guinness World Record for memory by recalling the exact order of 59 decks of shuffled playing cards.
He created 'The Farrow Method' to help combat his severe dyslexia and ADHD and this is now a certifiable memory system backed by a double-blind neuroscience study at McGill University. Dave has been a featured guest on Dr. Oz, Steve Harvey, The Today Show, Discovery Channel and many others. Most recently, he won the grand prize on episode 5 of the hit FOX TV show; SuperHuman.

title: Ben's Magnetic Memory Method Question Re Language Learning Credibility
description:
I got a great question from Ben recently regarding the Magnetic Memory Method for language learning. 

More importantly, his question is about the credibility of using this method for language learning. 

Let me tell you:

This is a wonderful and important question. 

Why? 

Because there are no short cuts in language learning. At least, not in the way a lot of people are hoping for. 

But there are tools and strategies far better than any short cut ...

... incredible and powerful ways that help you move faster and retain more words and phrases. 

Improving your memory and HOW you use it is one of those ways. It's not a magic bullet, but if there is "real magic" out there ...

... that magic is to be found in the place where memory techniques meet your mind and the fundamental rules of your brain. 

The overarching training I've put together is called the Magnetic Memory Method. 

It's backed by the best science in the world. It comes from a memory tradition that is thousands of years old. There are memory athletes who use similar tools to demonstrate the power of any person's brain ... but above all ...

... there is YOU. 

I have loads of stories to tell from the roads I've traveled using memory techniques as a fluency booster and cornerstone of what I call The Big Five of Language Learning. 

My website is loaded with testimonials too:

https://www.magneticmemorymethod.com/testimonials/

But at the end of the day, the Magnetic Memory Method is an approach that places the power of using memory techniques to improve how you remember vocabulary and phrases in your hands.

It essentially helps you see your mind as a laboratory in which you play the role of "language learning scientist." 

As in any lab, there are procedures to follow. They're all documented and ready to go. You just need to learn them and then reproduce the experiments that have produced success for so many others in your own lab. 

It is the perfect science. 

And when you're ready, I invite you to bring these tools into your lab and use them to "magnetize" the words and phrases constantly slipping your memory into long term memory. 

Follow the universal principles and modify them to your own experience and you'll have no problem getting the information into long term memory. 

It's fast, easy, effective and fun. Before you know it, you'll be like the hundreds of others who have asked me the most common question in the world: 

Why aren't these memory and learning techniques taught in schools? 

The answer is fun to discuss. 

But that just takes time away from you learning your language. 

And it takes time away from you being one of those who is helping spread the good news about memory techniques so that others can learn in the absence of help from schools. 

When you're ready, if you'd like to give my new program Fluency a try, just click here: 

https://www.magneticmemorymethod.com/yt-fluency

I'm confident you'll have the adventure of a lifetime, boost your fluency at measurable speeds, make new friends along the way and finally scratch learning that language off your bucket list. Wouldn't that be great? 

See you inside! :)

Sincerely, 

Anthony

title: üö™PAO Problems And Memory Palace Questions Only You Can Answer
description:
Looking for a PAO system? Well, start with the basics of the Memory Palace first with my FREE Memory Improvement Kit:

https://www.magneticmemorymethod.com/yt

Then, whether your should or shouldn't use Person Action Object  (PAO) mnemonics isn't really the point of this live, but you will get some great insights related to this powerful memory tool. 

Here's an older Magnetic Memory Method Podcast about PAO/Person Action Object:

https://www.magneticmemorymethod.com/mmmp-013-the-amazing-relationship-between-memory-serial-killers-and-bees/

And here's one of the more recent questions that inspired this Magnetic Memory Method YouTube Live:

I‚Äôd love to ask for your advice on a PAO system I am working on for my family to use:

Background:

I have thought about encoding 8 to 12 digits along a journey in each location by using an enhanced PAO system from 0-99, I call PACO (Person, Action, Object + a Container) 

The container is a different kind of object that only works because I ensure the types are mutually exclusive.  I plan to later add a discrete food object and a discrete pet to each double digit as well.
See the list below for example. The rationale for this is that I work in a data intensive industry (valuing and helping to buy/sell companies), where memorizing many figures, stats, and historical charts would be of great use. I‚Äôm not as interested in rapidly memorizing a deck of cards, though I wouldn‚Äôt mind spending some time on that later...

To support this system, I follow certain restrictions: 
The Person can‚Äôt be a pet/animal type
The Object is usually a small thing done with a verb
The Container is a large thing that houses people/animals. 
I‚Äôm trying to make this a kid friendly system for my family and thus I stay away from the R-rated options 

My long term thought is that I can have a person doing an action on an object frozen in my mind inside of a container. Each of these PACOs could be eating a food and own a pet. Thus, in one loci, if it is graphic and memorable enough, I can encode up to 6 double digit items. I‚Äôm just wondering if this is overkill and what may be the best way to get my brain to internalize the PACOs. My question is, should I develop a separate journey of 110 location (perhaps 11 rooms of 10 loci), which I use to memorize the PACOs? Also, if I start with just the traditional PAO and add the additional C later, will that be counterproductive to just memorizing all the options up front? Do you have any other advice on how I can most effectively internalize the system, so that I just about think of pictures in place of double digits?


Thank you for any thoughts on this topic!


***

My thoughts on a pao memory system and the best way to make a pao are in this video, along with other Method of Loci corrections to the ancient art of memory and I can't wait to hear more interesting questions like these for discussion on future MMM Lives. 

Talk soon! :)

Sincerely, 

Anthony Metivier

P.S. Many people focus on creating a 0-99 PAO system. Make sure you do 00-99. It's better. :)

description:

4. Know and understand the power and potential of ghosting and the Ugly Sister Effect. They‚Äôre similar but not the same and can always be an asset. There‚Äôs no reason why they should ever be a harm.

title: Aphantasia And The Memory Palace Technique
description:
Worried that aphantasia or the inability to see images in your mind will stop you from using the Memory Palace technique? 

Don't be. 

As I discuss in this video and in greater depth on the Magnetic Memory Method blog, I don't have this condition, but I'm low on the visual threshold. Most of what I do involves thinking about  strange combinations of images IN WORDS, not HDTV - just as I had always done as an avid reader of books. 

Here's the full blog post:

https://www.magneticmemorymethod.com/aphantasia/

Even though I don't have aphantasia, I DO take it seriously. 

It would be years before I started actively practicing "seeing" the descriptions in books - and yet somehow I still enjoyed hundreds of novels without seeing a think in my mind.

Then this update on an what might give clues to an aphantasia cure emerged:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=y0Z88TSKejw

Over the years, I've invested in myself so that I can "see" something like imagery in my mind. But even to this day, the best results I get from memory techniques don't require HD television on the back of my eyelids.

Never.

It's just thoughts.

But there are some people, on the other hand, who see images very easily in their mind. And the can benefit a great deal from spending more time with words and concepts.

And just as a preview of something coming up, I'm doing some research now on "aphantasia," a condition in which people can't visualize in their minds whatsoever.

And yet here's the thing: 

People with this condition are amongst the most creative people in the world and Penn Jillette to take perhaps the most famous example, has talked about how he remembers things perfectly well so long as he verbalizes them.

He doesn't need to see anything in his mind at all to remember!

Plus, one of the guys who did a lot of work on Facebook and has pics with Zuckerberg all over his page also has this condition. Not being able to see in his mind doesn't seem to have stopped him from remembering all kinds of numbers and achieving all kinds of great things in life.

So listen: no matter who or where you are in your imaginative life, there's no reason you can't learn, remember and recall anything you want for the rest of you life using simple memory techniques. And I can help you magnetize and empower beyond your wildest imagination.

If you'd like to hear Penn Jillette talk about his experiences with aphantasia, go here: 

http://pennsundayschool.com/episodes/ Find episode 174 and scrub to the 1h15m mark.

Also, AphantasiaMeow is also doing great work with helping people discover how to experience having a mind's eye:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LA0ZUj7Wtmc&lc=

Here's Jonathan Levi on Aphantasia too:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6n_KyqrPriQ

Hope this helps you out and look forward to hearing your stories of triumph when you dive in with memory techniques no matter where you currently stand with aphantasia and the ability to see imagery in your mind. 

Sincerely, 

Anthony Metivier
www.magneticmemorymethod.com

title: Dumplings, Actually (Chinese Memory Techniques In Berlin Vlog)
description:
Free Memory Training With Memory Palace Worksheets And Videos: http://www.magneticmemorymethod.com/free-memory-improvement-kit/

Except for the threats, the sirens and the guys with guns ... last night was amazing for my memory. 

First, April got invited to make dumplings to celebrate the last day of Autumn and the first day of Winter on the Chinese calendar. 

I love the Magnetic Memory Method because I was able to remember those words in Chinese ...

Autumn

Winter

Crazy thing is ... I'd only heard them once in my life and used an impromptu Memory Palace to memorize them.

Months later ... 

Still intact. 

Sure, I had a bit of a pronunciation problem, but that's muscle memory. It's understandable that words you don't use for months that you only heard once don't exactly snap into place. 

But what a GREAT feeling to be able to remember them! And all by doing something I really love: 

Using my memory.

After that, we were shooting video and getting into more of the particulars about how all this works. 

We wound up getting a bit lost and keeping warm inside the bank machine area of a building.

And that's when the threats and guns appeared. 

Turns out, that a guy didn't like me having the camera on while April was teaching me how to say, "I'm lost" in Chinese. 

Good thing the Magnetic Memory Method teaches relaxation as part of the memory technique ...

You certainly need to be calm when a stranger starts telling you what you can and cannot do.

It's hard managing your defensive instincts and memory at the same time.

(You'll laugh when you see my reaction in the video and the guns that were there to keep us safe all along).

So yes, April and I survived.

And the coolest thing is that I was still able to memorize "I am lost" in Chinese. 

And that's what this video about using memory techniques to learn Chinese is all about. 

Wanna join me as I use a special tool to help with my Chinese? 

Here's something you gotta try:

http://www.magneticmemorymethod.com/chinese-vault

Have fun and talk soon! :)

Sincerely, 

Anthony Metivier

title: Leaving Berlin Part One (Fave Memory Palace City Ever!)
description:
Want my FREE Memory Improvement Kit? 

If so, it will help you:

* Learn anything at laser fast speeds

* Dramatically improve your understanding of information

* Eliminate the frustration of forgetting

https://www.magneticmemorymethod.com/yt

In this video I talk about how I'm spending time collecting my memories of Berlin and one fave Memory Palace in particular. 

We were also recording the theme song for my new Self-Improvement Supercharger Podcast. But more news about that soon. 

For now, here's a quick message I just emailed out that you might find interesting:

A few years ago a lot of things took place all at once. 

The short version of the story is that my research grant had ended. I had no job. And I had no home. 

I was living in a basement suite while housesitting for a Canadian author and photographer. 

Literally a mattress on the floor. 

My life was in shambles. 

I‚Äôd had success and lost it all. 

Then I tried to start a ‚Äúmentoring‚Äù company. 

I couldn‚Äôt stand the idea of being a tutor. Students, I reasoned, don‚Äôt need help with their existing assignments. They need someone to give them assignments that make them so good at school they simply laugh at what their teachers throw at them.

Actually, that company didn‚Äôt do too poorly. 

The only problem is that I didn‚Äôt know how to market it. 

And in truth, I wasn‚Äôt suited for the work. 

My heart was in the right place, but I just didn‚Äôt have ‚Ä¶ ‚Äúit.‚Äù 

Through a mysterious set of twists and turns, I wound up discovering a number of people who had learned to master their lives. 

At first, I was skeptical.

Some days, I still am. 

After all, it‚Äôs NEVER as easy as people make it seem. 

By the same token, it can be a lot easier. 

And one of the people who has made my life a lot is easier is Michael Hyatt. 

I‚Äôm a hard working fellow. 

When I take a training, I take it seriously. 

I follow the instructions. 

And I expect my students to do the same. 

Otherwise, there‚Äôs no point. 

Nothing to be gained. 

If you‚Äôre teachable, I want to reward you.

I want to introduce you to one of my teachers. 

I want to give you every possible incentive to learn from him.

And I want you to do it by clicking on this link and following the instructions on the page. (It‚Äôs a quick read with lots of enticing pictures, so don‚Äôt hesitate for a second to check it out.)

Then I want you to enjoy what Michael Hyatt has in store for you. 

Later, I‚Äôll be sending you some gifts later to thank you for taking action. 

Those gifts will make your 2017 even more fabulous. 

Some of you will get more gifts than others.

But all of you will receive the absolute best Michael has to give.

Because when I‚Äôve simply followed the instructions teachers like Michael have laid out, I‚Äôve gone from sleeping on the floor to living out things I only ever dreamed of before.

Things like ‚Ä¶

Traveling the world ‚Ä¶ 

Having time to learn a new language ‚Ä¶

Teaching hundreds of thousands of people around the world ‚Ä¶

Click the link at the top of the description box right now for information about how you can do the same. 

Sincerely, 

Anthony

title: How To Effectively Filter Out Useless Information
description:
For the Top Resource in this video, click: http://www.magneticmemorymethod.com/bye-bonus

Here‚Äôs the question I‚Äôm answering in the video in full: 

Hi there and greetings from Finland!

My question is both simple and broad, and it has to do with your great post on memorizing textbooks. In short, one could formulate it as this:

How to effectively filter the most important bits of information to memorize when studying large and confusing topics?

I'm a student of comparative literature and philosophy at The University of Helsinki. Recently my mnemonic efforts have concerned memorizing large courses such as "Introduction to Epistemology", including textbooks and lectures.

The information is obviously quite theoretical and the materials cover a bit of everything on the subject. Sometimes the lectures are ill-organized and materials only partly relevant to the subject.

For me, coming up with colourful images and creating well-functioning memory palaces is relatively easy. The hard part is to figure out what to memorize in the first place. In your post about textbook memorizing that would be the part of "finding the big points and jotting them down".

For example, with the "Introduction to Epistemology" course I used 90 % of my study time just filtering and organizing the messy theoretical information in memorizable chunks. And not only finding the right things but also shaping them so that the "big points" are actually big, memorizable, and dense with information.

But unfortunately I can't help myself feeling insecure and unmotivated. Have I really found the right things? Or have I just wasted my limited study time? And why does it feel so overwhelming ‚Äì like comparing weight lifting with walking through the gym's sliding door after the practice.

I'm aware that my question is a bit off concerning your method. But since I have understood that you have studied film and philosophy successfully with mnemonics, I would be very glad to hear your insights and tips on this.

Thankfully yours,

Mikael

The resources I mention in the video include: 

How to Memorize A Textbook: http://www.magneticmemorymethod.com/how-to-memorize-a-textbook/

The Helsinki Memory Palace video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=llo3Ee4Z6Us

Audiobook Builder: http://www.splasm.com/audiobookbuilder/

Modern Intellectual Tradition: From Descartes to Derrida: http://www.thegreatcourses.com/courses/modern-intellectual-tradition-from-descartes-to-derrida.html

Classic Rick Roderick video on YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sDqDJJcJAOg

As mentioned in the video, please let me know how I can make Q&A videos like these better for you. 

And if you aren‚Äôt already subscribed, you can subscribe to this channel here: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCdIwC3d4CRjrrQdaqZaNBpA

Thanks as ever for your support and talk soon! :)

Sincerely, 

Anthony

title: Memory Techniques And The Power Of Making Mistakes With Mnemonics
description:
Grab this FREE Memory Improvement Kit: http://www.magneticmemorymethod.com/free-memory-improvement-kit/

One of the things I love about my job is practicing what I preach. And as they say in the comics, with great power comes great responsibility.

So that‚Äôs why in this video I‚Äôm opening up to share with you some of the mistakes I make, from simple stuff like the title of Dali‚Äôs Persistence of Memory, to pronunciation errors. 

When it comes to using mnemonics and other memory techniques (like a Memory Palace), you will make mistakes. 

But don‚Äôt fear them! Mistakes are your best friend. They will help you get things correct so long as you don‚Äôt let them freak you out. 

If they do get you frustrated or upset ‚Ä¶ you‚Äôre turning them into a monster. And that‚Äôs the last thing you want.

title: How To Remember Seat Numbers
description:
http://www.magneticmemorymethod.com/major-method

Some people call the Major Method the Major System to remember numbers. 

Whatever you want to call it, it's fun and easy to remember numbers, even simple seat numbers. 

What might seem like a simple and easy string of numbers ... 

Not so much for me. I really will forget even my train and seat numbers if I don't use some kind of memory technique. Of all memory techniques for numbers, the Major Method is my go to because it's so flexible.  

I highly recommend you take a second to learn it. Many people find it life changing and I'm convinced you will too.

title: Using Historical Sites As A Memory Palace To Remember Facts
description:
Using a historical site as Memory Palace is simple. This FREE Memory Improvement Kit shows you how: http://www.magneticmemorymethod.com/free-memory-improvement-kit/

Jonathan Levi of SuperLearner (http://www.magneticmemorymethod.com/superlearnermain) and I had a blast in Jerusalem recently. To make sure it was even more fun than usual, we used the main historical site we visited as a Memory Palace. 

As you'll see, it's easy to memorize historical dates on the site itself. We also reveal a few of our weaknesses and foibles with the memory techniques. Learn from our mistakes with mnemonics so you don't have to suffer. 

Enjoy this memory training and let us know if you have questions. We might answer them on a future video or podcast! :)

Sincerely, 

Anthony Metivier

title: 3 Ways To Develop Trust In Your Memory
description:
You can develop even more trust in your memory with this FREE Memory Improvement Kit: http://www.magneticmemorymethod.com/free-memory-improvement-kit/

Memory improvement isn't only about using a Memory Palace and mnemonics. It's about learning how to trust your memory.

And frankly, that can be a scary thing to do. After all, you have to take risks, get out there and actually commit some things to memory using the tools on hand. 

But if you're willing to do that, then the 3 tips in this video will help you a great deal with developing your memory. You'll reach your memory improvement goals in record time and have a lot of fun doing it. 

It's fun. It's easy. It's Magnetic. 

Sincerely, 

Anthony Metivier

title: 5 Reaons You Should Remember Something Every Day
description:
Don't know how to learn, memorize and recall information? Get this FREE Memory Improvement Kit: 
http://www.magneticmemorymethod.com/free-memory-improvement-kit/

Just a quick video about why you should remember something every day. It's really astonishing what can happen when you do. 

Likewise, it's astonishing what can happen when you don't ... like memory decay and all kinds of terrible cognitive problems. 

The good news is that with memory techniques and tools like the Magnetic Memory Method, you'll be in a good position to learn, remember and recall anything you wish in a snap. 

Obviously the Memory Palace is a core technique you'll want to learn, but there's more to it and so I hope to see you on www.magneticmemorymethod.com for more so you can enjoy these simple techniques and expand the life of your mind.

title: Using Memory Techniques When You Have The Flu
description:

Remember when I talked about The Big Five Of Language Learning in this video: 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bR15aAXv-F0

But what if you get the flu? 

In this video, I answer everything, another video in the health playlist here on the Magnetic Memory Method YouTube channel. 

How about you? How do you keep up with your language learning goals when you get a sickness like the flu? Am I just pushing it or is it good to keep active? 

As always, thanks for watching and talk soon! :)

Sincerely, 

Anthony Metivier

title: Learn German With Jason Bourne And The Newspaper
description:
Just a taste of what's going on in the Learn German with Memory Hacks closed Facebook group: https://www.facebook.com/groups/germanmemoryhacks/

I don't know about you, but I have a lot of fun with my ongoing quest to learn German better using memory techniques. This video shows you a super-simple way to memorize new words simply by scanning the newspaper. 

In this case, we're using the Magnetic Memory Method to learn German by reading a story about the upcoming Jason Bourne film.

It's especially great because Jason Bourne is already so memorable. As you'll see in the video, that makes it even easier to use as a figure in the mnemonics. If you know how to make an MMM Bridging Figure, all the better. 

I'd love to have you inside the group. :)

Anthony Metivier

title: Police Station Memory Palace
description:
Sometimes finding a new Memory Palace is as easy as walking into the nearest police station. Here's more tips on finding a good Memory Palace: http://www.magneticmemorymethod.com/how-to-find-memory-palaces/

Jonathan Levi and I (he's another Memory Palace fan and expert with memory techniques) went to report on the criminal destruction of his bicycle. 

While he was speaking with the officer, I listened deeply to their Hebrew. 

Not because I currently want to learn Hebrew (though I really do if I'm honest with myself. No, I was listening as an experiment. 

Could I isolate a couple of words I heard, memorize them and then associate the meaning of those words later? It's a bit of an Ebbinghaus effect, in the sense that he said you can easily memorize nonsense syllables. 

And of course it's true. 

Anyhow, this video is just a discussion of showing how I made an impromptu Memory Palace and learned some new words in Hebrew. We'll test later how many I can remember, all without writing them down. 

Here's a conversation on Jonathan's podcast that will teach you more about using your memory to learn and memorize more: 

http://www.becomingasuperhuman.com/dr-anthony-metivier-remember-anything-everything-podcast/

I really hope that if you're learning a language (or anything), you'll realize just how easy it is to quickly learn, memorize and recall information with stunningly high levels of accuracy. And if you need more help, here's a FREE Memory Improvement kit to help you:

www.magneticmemorymethod.com/free-memory-improvement-kit/

Thanks as always for watching and please feel free to jump in on the discussion below with your comments. Click like and share this material as well if you want to help join the Mnemonics Renaissance and help people learn faster in ways that are easy, elegant, effective and fun! :)

title: "Virtual Memory Palace" Memory Technique Q&A
description:

http://www.magneticmemorymethod.com/how-to-enhance-your-memory-with-virtual-memory-palaces/

Using a Memory Palace is simple, but using an imaginary one adds a layer of complexity that may or may not be useful to you. In the long run, myself and many others have found that for practical memory improvement purposes, Memory Palaces based on real locations tend to serve best. 

What have your experiences been?

title: How To Memorize VAT Tax Law Facebook Live Q&A
description:
More FREE memory training with the Magnetic Memory Method Memory Improvement Kit: http://www.magneticmemorymethod.com/free-memory-improvement-kit/

Hey there, 

I just did my first Facebook Q&A to answer the top three questions in my inbox. The first is about tax law - kind of dry and boring, but I suggest exactly why that's the last thing to focus on. 

Crazy thing is, I'm now having so much fun revisiting Patrick Bateman in the impromptu Memory Palace that I can't stop thinking about VAT tax law ... Maybe I should become an accountant!

I also go over the truth about Anki and other spaced-repetition software. If you want to use them in hybrid form with memory techniques, here's a solid understanding of how. 

Hope you enjoy. Leave a comment, share the video and head over to http://www.magneticmemorymethod.com/contact if you have questions you'd like to have covered on future live Facebook Live Q&A. :)

Here's my Facebook page, by the way: 

https://www.facebook.com/Anthony-Metivier-480537711995886/

You can join the Magnetic Memory Method Facebook group here as well: 

https://www.facebook.com/groups/404833969708982/

Thanks for watching and talk soon! :)

Sincerely, 

Anthony Metivier

title: Unbroken Meditation Record: How to Remember to Meditate
description:
The evidence that meditation improves your memory is here: 


https://www.magneticmemorymethod.com/how-to-improve-concentration-and-memory-buddha-style/

But in this video I'm talking about how to get the job of meditation done so that you never skip a day. 

Having a daily meditation routine is critical for well-being. You really can't know just how profound it is until you try, which is why it makes sense to get started a.s.a.p.

For more next level stuff, you can check out how my mediation routine meets up with my Mandarin Chinese studies here:

http://www.magneticmemorymethod.com/mandarin-chinese-mnemonics/

Enjoy your meditation journey and don't forget to use memory techniques. :)

title: Lamictal Withdrawal And My Memory Experiments
description:
Lamictal withdrawal isn't interfering with my memory techniques, which is good. All thanks to what you can learn in this free memory improvement kit:

http://www.magneticmemorymethod.com/free-memory-improvement-kit/

I've got some more of my story with dealing with these issues here:

www.magneticmemorymethod.com/memory-improvement-tips-for-the-manic-depressive-university-student/

www.magneticmemorymethod.com/robin-williams-and-the-most-unusable-memory-palace-in-the-world/

How I've opened up about this issue has helped quite a few people, so I hope that will continue by sharing this journey with Bipolar Disorder and the like. For the time being, no more lamictal and hopefully all the withdrawal will be gone soon.
